div.p: ENGLISH-MEN For my Money: OR, A pleasant Comedy, called, A Woman will haue her Will.
Imprinted at London by W. White, dwelling in Cow-lane. 1616.

sp.speaker: Pisaro.
sp.l: HOw smugge this gray-eyde Morning seemes to bee,
A pleasant sight; but yet more pleasure haue I
To thinke vpon this moystning Southwest Winde,
That driues my laden Shippes from fertile Spaine:
But come what will, no Winde can come amisse,
For two and thirty Windes that rules the Seas,
And blowes about this ayerie Region;
Thirtie two Shippes haue I to equall them:
Whose wealthy fraughts doe make Pisaro rich:
Thus euery Soyle to mee is naturall:
Indeed by birth, I am a Portingale,
Who driuen by Westerne winds on English shore,
Heere liking of the soyle, I maried,
And haue Three Daughters: But impartiall Death
Long since, depriude mee of her dearest life:
Since whose discease, in London I haue dwelt:
And by the sweete loude trade of Usurie,
Letting for Interest, and on Morgages.
Doe I waxe rich, though many Gentlemen
By my extortion comes to miserie:
Amongst the rest, three English Gentlemen,
Haue pawnde to mee their Liuings and their Lands:
Each seuerall hoping, though their hopes are vaine,
By mariage of my Daughters, to possesse
Their Patrimonies and their Landes againe:
But Gold is sweete, and they deceiue them-selues;
For though I guild my Temples with a smile,
It is but Iudas-like, to worke their endes.
But soft, What noyse of footing doe I heare?

div.stage: Enter Laurentia, Marina, Mathea, and Anthony.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Now Maister, what intend you to read to vs?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: Pisaro your Father would haue me read morall Philosophy.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: First tell mee how you like it?

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.p: First tell vs what it is.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: They be my Daughters and their Schoole-maister, Pisaro, not a word, but list their talke.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Gentlewomen, to paint Philosophy,
Is to present youth with so sowre a dish,
As their abhorring stomackes nill digestes.
When first my mother Oxford (Englands pride)
Fostred mee puple-like, with her rich store,
My study was to read Philosophy:
But since, my head-strong youths vnbridled will,
Scorning the leaden fetters of restraint,
Hath prunde my feathers to a higher pitch.
Gentlewomen, Morall Philosophy is a kind of art,
The most contrary to your tender sexes;
It teacheth to be graue: and on that brow,
Where Beawtie in her rarest glory shines,
Plants the sad semblance of decayed age:
Those Weedes that with their riches should adorne,
And grace faire Natures curious workmanship,
Must be conuerted to a blacke fac'd vayle,
Griefes liuerie, and Sorrowes semblance:
Your food must be your hearts aboundant sighes,
Steep'd in the brinish licquor of your teares:
Day-light as darke-night, darke-night spent in prayer:
Thoughts your companions, and repentant mindes,
The recreation of your tired spirits:
Gentlewomen, if you can like this modestie,
Then will I read to you Philosophy.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: Fie vpon it.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.p: Hang vp Philosophy, Ile none of it.

sp.speaker: Pisar.
sp.p: A Tutor said I; a Tutor for the Diuell.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: No Gentlewomen, Anthony hath learn'd
To read a Lector of more pleasing worth.
Marina, read these lines, young Haruie sent them,
There euery line repugnes Philosophy:
Then loue him, for he hates the thing thou hates.
Laurentia, this is thine from Ferdinande:
Thinke euery golden circle that thou see'st,
The rich vnualued circle of his worthe.
Mathea, with these Gloues thy Ned salutes thee;
As often as these, hide these from the Sunne,
And Wanton steales a kisse from thy faire hand,
Presents his seruiceable true harts zeale,
Which waites vpon the censure of thy doome:
What though their Lands be morgag'd to your Father;
Yet may your Dowries redeeme that debt:
Thinke they are Gentlemen, and thinke they loue;
And be that thought, their true loues aduocate.
Say you should wed for Wealth; for to that scope
Your Fathers greedy disposition tendes,
The world would say, that you were had for Wealth,
And so faire Beawties honour quite distinct:
A masse of Wealth being powrde vpon another,
Little augments the shew, although the summe;
But beeing lightly scattred by it selfe,
It doubles what it seem'd, although but one:
Euen so your selues, for wedded to the Rich,
His stile was as it was, a Rich man still:
But wedding these, to wed true Loue, is dutie:
You make them rich in Wealth, but more in Beawtie:
I need not plead that smile, that smile shewes hearts consent,
That kisse shew'd loue, that on that gift was lent:
And last thine Eyes, that teares of true ioy sendes,
As comfortable tidings for my friends.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Haue done, haue done; what need'st thou more procure,
When long ere this I stoop'd to that faire lure:
Thy euer louing Haruie I delight it:
Marina euer louing shall requite it young.
Teach vs Philosphy? Ile be no Nunne;
Age scornes Delight, I loue it being:
There's not a word of this, not a words part,
But shall be stamp'd, seal'd, printed on my heart;
On this Ile read, on this my senses ply:
All Arts being vaine, but this Philosophy.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Why was I made a Mayde, but for a Man?
And why Laurentia, but for Ferdinand?
The chastest Soule these Angels could intice?
Much more himselfe, an Angell of more price:
were't thy selfe present, as my heart could wish,
Such vsage thou shouldst haue, as I giue this.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: Then you would kisse him?

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: If I did, how then?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: Nay I say nothing to it, but Amen.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: The Clarke must haue his fees, Ile pay you them.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Good God, how abiect is this single life,
Ile not abide it; Father, Friends, nor Kin,
Shall once disswade me from affecting:
A man's a man; and Ned is more then one:
Y fayth Ile haue thee Ned, or Ile haue none;
Doe what they can, chafe, chide, or storme their fill,
Mathea is resolu'd to haue her will.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: I can no longer hold my patience.
Impudent villanie, and laciuious Girles,
I haue ore-heard your vild conuersions:
You scorne Philosophy: You'le be no Nunne,
You must needes kisse the Pursse, because he sent it.
And you forsooth, you flurgill, minion,
A brat scant folded in the dozens at most,
Youle haue your will forsooth; What will you haue?

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: But twelue yeare old? nay Father that's not so,
Our Sexton told mee I was three yeares mo.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: I say but twelue: you'r best tell mee I lye.
What sirra Anthony.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: Heere sir.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Come here sir, & you light huswiues get you in:
Stare not vpon me, moue me not to ire: Exeunt sisters.
Nay sirra stay you here, Ile talke with you:
Did I retaine thee (villaine) in my house,
Gaue thee a stipend twenty Markes by yeare,
And hast thou thus infected my three Girles,
Vrging the loue of those, I most abhord;
Vnthrifts, Beggers; what is worse,
And all because they are your Country-men?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: Why sir, I taught them not to keepe a Marchants Booke, or cast accompt: yet to a word much like that word Accounte.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: A Knaue past grace, is past recouerie.
Why sirra Frisco, Villaine, Loggerhead, where art thou?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Heere's a calling indeed; a man were better to liue a Lords life and doe nothing, then a Seruing creature, and neuer be idle. Oh Maister, what a messe of Brewesse standes now vpon the poynt of spoyling by your hastinesse; why they were able to haue got a good Stomacke with child euen with the sight of them; and for a Vapour, oh precious Vapour, let but a Wench come neere them with a Painted face, and you should see the Paint drop and curdle on her Cheekes, like a peece of dry Essex Cheese toasted at the fire.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Well sirra, leaue this thought, & minde my words,
Giue diligence, inquire about
For one that is expert in Languages,
A good Musitian, and a French-man borne;
And bring him hither to instruct my Daughters,
Ile nere trust more a smooth-fac'd English-man.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p:
What, must I bring one that can speake Languages?
what an old Asse is my Maister; why he may speake flaunte taunte as well as French, for I cannot vnderstand him.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: If he speake French, thus he will say, Awee awee:
What, canst thou remember it?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Oh, I haue it now, for I remember my great Grandfathers Grandmothers sisters coosen told mee, that Pigges and French-men, speake one Language, awee awee; I am Dogg at this: But what must he speake else?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Dutch.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Let's heare it?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Haunce butterkin slowpin.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Oh this is nothing, for I can speake perfect Dutch when I list.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Can you, I pray let's heare some?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Nay I must haue my mouth full of Meate first, and then you shall heare me grumble it foorth full mouth, as Haunce Butterkin slowpin frokin: No, I am a simple Dutchman: Well, Ile about it.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Stay sirra, you are too hastie; for hee must speake one Language more.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: More Languages? I trust he shall haue Tongues enough for one mouth: But what is the third?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Italian.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Why that is the easiest of all, for I can tell whether he haue any Italian in him euen by looking on him.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Can you so, as how?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Marry by these three poynts; a Wanton Eye. Pride in his Apparell, and the Diuell in his Countenance. Well, God keepe me from the Diuel in seeking this French-man: But doe you heare mee Maister, what shall my fellow Anthony doe, it seemes he shall serue for nothing but to put Lattin into my young Mistresses.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Hence asse, hence loggerhead, begon I say.
And now to you that reades Philosophy,
Packe from my house, I doe discharge thy seruice,
And come not neere my dores; for if thou dost,
Ile make thee a publike example to the world.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Well crafty Fox, you that worke by wit,
It may be, I may liue to fit you yet.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Ah sirra, this tricke was spide in time,
For if but two such Lectures more they'd heard,
For euer had their honest names been marde:
Ile in and rate them: yet that's not best,
The Girles are wilfull, and seueritie
May make them carelesse, mad, or desperate.
What shall I doe? Oh! I haue found it now,
There are three wealthy Marchants in the Towne,
All Strangers, and my very speciall friendes,
The one of them is an Italian:
A French-man, and a Dutch-man, be the other:
These three intyrely doe affect my Daughters,
And therefore meane I, they shall haue the tongues,
That they may answere in their seuerall Language:
But what helpes that? they must not stay so long,
For whiles they are a learning Languages,
My English Youths, both wed, and bed them too:
Which to preuent, Ile seeke the Strangers out,
Let's looke: tis past aleauen, Exchange time full,
There shall I meete them, and conferre with them,
This worke craues hast, my Daughters must be Wedde,
For one Months stay, sayth farrewell Mayden head.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Come Gentlemen, w'are almost at the house,
I promise you this walke ore Tower-hill,
Of all the places London can afforde,
Hath sweetest Ayre, and fitting our desires.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Good reason, so it leades to Croched-Fryers
Where old Pisaro, and his Daughters dwell,
Looke to your feete, the broad way leades to Hell:
They say Hell standes below, downe in the deepe,
Ile downe that Hill, where such good Wenches keepe,
But sirra Ned, what sayes Mathea to thee?
Wilt fadge? wilt fadge? What, will it be a match?

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: A match say you? a mischiefe twill as soone:
Should I can scarce begin to speake to her,
But I am interrupted by her father.
Ha, what say you? and then put ore his snoute,
Able to shaddow Powles, it is so great.
Well, tis no matter, sirrs, this is his House,
Knocke for the Churle bid him bring out his Daughter;
Ile, sbloud I will, though I be hanged for it,

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Hoyda, hoyda, nothing with you but vp & ride,
Youle be within, ere you can reach the Dore,
And haue the Wench, before you compasse her:
You are too hastie, Pisaro is a man,
Not to be fedde with Words, but wonne with Gold.
But who comes heere?

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Whom, Anthony our friend?
Say man, how fares our Loues? How doth Mathea?
Can she loue Ned? how doth she like my sute?
Will old Pisaro take me for his Sonne;
For I thanke God, he kindly takes our Landes,
Swearing, Good Gentlemen you shall not want,
Whilst old Pisaro, and his credite holds:
He will be damn'd the Roage, before he do't?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Prethy talke milder: let but thee alone,
And thou in one bare hower will aske him more,
Then heele remember in a hundred yeares:
Come from him Anthony, and say what newes?

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: The newes for me is badd; and this it is:
Pisaro hath discharg'd me of his seruice.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Discharg'd thee of his seruice; for what cause?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: Nothing, but that his Daughters learne Philosophy.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.p: Maydes should reade, that it teacheth modestie.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: I, but I left out mediocritie,
And with effectuall reasons, vrgd your loues.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: The fault was small, we three will to thy Maister
And begge thy pardon.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Oh, that cannot be,
Hee hates you farre worser, then he hates me;
For all the loue he shewes, is for your Lands,
Which he hopes sure will fall into his hands:
Yet Gentlemen, this comfort take of me,
His Daughters to your loues affected be:
Their father is abroad, they three at home,
Goe chearely in, and cease that is your owne:
And for my selfe, but grace what I intend,
Ile ouerreach the Churle, and helpe my Frend.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Build on our helpes, and but deuise the meanes.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Pisaro did commaund Frisco his man,
(A simple sotte, kept onely but for myrth)
To inquire about in London for a man,
That were a French-man and Musitian,
To be (as I suppose) his Daughters Tutor:
Him if you meete, as like enough you shall,
He will inquire of you of his affayres;
Then make him answere, you three came from Paules,
And in the middle walke, one you espide,
Fit for his purpose; then discribe this Cloake,
This Beard and Hatte: for in this borrowed shape,
Must I beguile and ouer-reach the Foole:
The Maydes must be acquainted with this drift.
The Doore doth ope, I dare not stay reply,
Least beeing discride: Gentlemen adue,
And helpe him now, that oft hath helped you.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: How now sirra, whither are you going?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Whither am I going, how shall I tell you, when I doe not know my selfe, nor vnderstand my selfe?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: What dost thou meane by that?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Marry sir, I am seeking a Needle in a Bottle of Hay, a Monster in the liknesse of a Man: one that in stead of good morrow, asketh what Porrage you haue to Dinner, Parley vous signiour? one that neuer washes his fingers, but lickes them cleane with kisses; a clipper of the Kings English: and to conclude, an eternall enemie to all good Language.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.p: What's this? what's this?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Doe not you smell me? Well, I perceiue that witte doth not always dwel in a Satten-dublet: why, tis a Frenchman, Bassimon cue, how doe you?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.p: I thanke you sir, but tell me what wouldest thou doe with a French-man:

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Nay fayth, I would doe nothing with him, vnlesse I set him to teach Parrets to speake: marry the old Asse my Maister, would haue him to teach his Daughters, though I trust the whole world sees, that there be such in his house that can serue his Daughters turne, as well as the proudest French-man: but if you be good laddes, tell me where I may finde such a man?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: We will, goe hye thee straight to Paules,
There shalt thou find one fitting thy desire;
Thou soone mayst know him, for his Beard is blacke,
Such is his rayment, if thou runn'st appace,
Thou canst not misse him Frisco.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p:
Lord, Lord, how shall poore Phrisco rewarde your rich tydings Gentlemen: I am yours till Shrouetewesday, for then change I my Coppy, & looke like nothing but Red-Herring Cobbes, and Stock-Fish; yet Ile doe somewhat for you in the meane time: my Maister is abroad, and my young Mistresses at home: if you can doe any good on them before the French-man corne, why so? Ah Gentlemen, doe not suffer a litter of Languages to spring vp amongst vs: I must to the Walke in Paules, you
to the Vestrie. Gentlemen, as to my selfe, and so foorth.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Fooles tell the truth men say, and so may he:
Wenches we come now, Loue our conduct be.
Ned, knocke at the doore: but soft forbeare;
The Cloude breakes vp, and our three Sunnes appeare.
To this I fly, shine bright my liues sole stay,
And make griefes night a gloryous summers day.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Gentlemen, how welcome you are here,
Guesse by our lookes, for other meanes by feare
Preuented is: our fathers quicke returne
Forbidds the welcome, else we would haue done.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Mathea, How these faythfull thoughts obey,

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: No more sweet loue, I know what thou would'st say:
You say you loue me, so I wish you still,
Loue hath loues hier, being ballancst with good will:
But say; come you to vs, or come you rather
To pawne more Lands for mony to our father?
I know tis so, a Gods name spend at large:
What man? our mariage day will all discharge;
Our father (by his leaue) must pardon vs,
Age saue of age, of nothing can discusse:
But in our loues, the prouerbe weele fulfill:
Women and Maydes, must alwayes haue their will.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Say thou as much, and adde life to this Coarse,

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: Your selfe & your good news doth more enforce:
How these haue set forth loue by all their witte,
I sweare in heart, I more then double it.
Sisters be glad, for he hath made it playne,
The meanes to get our Schoole-maister againe:
But Gentlemen, for this time cease our loues,
This open streete perhaps suspition moues,
Fayne we would stay, bid you walke in more rather,
But that we feare the comming of our father:
Goe to th' Exchange, craue Gold as you intend,
Pisaro scrapes for vs; for vs you spend:
We say farewell, more sadlier be bold,
Then would my greedy father to his Gold:
Wee here, you there, aske Gold; and Gold you shall:
Weele pay the intrest, and the principall. Exeunt Sisters

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: That's my good Girles, and Ile pay you for all.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Come to th' Exchange, and when I feele decay,
Send me such Wenches, Heauens I still shall pray.

div.stage: Enter Pisaro, Delion the Frenchman, Vandalle the Dutchman, Aluaro the Italian, and other Marchants, at seuerall doores.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Good morrow, M. Strangers.

sp.speaker: Strang.
sp.p: Good morrow sir.

sp.speaker: Pisaro.
sp.l: This (louing friends) hath thus emboldned me,
For knowing the affection and the loue
Maister Vandalle, that you beare my Daughter:
Likwise, and that with ioy considering too,
you Mounsier Delion, would faine dispatch:
I promise you, mee thinkes the time did fit,
And does bir-Lady too, in mine aduice,
This day to clap a full conclusion vp:
And therefore made I bold to call on you,
Meaning (our businesse done here at the Burse)
That you at mine intreaty should walke home,
And take in worth such Viands as I haue:
And then we would, and so I hope we shall,
Loosely tye vp the knot that you desire,
But for a day or two; and then Church rites
Shall sure conforme, confirme, and make all fast.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Seker Mester Pisaro, mee do so groterly dancke you, dat you macke mee so sure of de Wench, datt ic can neit dancke you genough.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p:
Monsieur Pisaro, mon pere, mon Vadere, Oh de
grande ioye you giue me (oconte) mee sal go home to your House, sal eat your Bakon, sal eat your Beefe, and shal tacke de Wench, de fine Damoysella.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: You shall, and welcome; welcome as my soule:
But were my third Sonne sweete Aluaro heere,
Wee would not stay at the Exchange to day,
But hye vs home and there end our affayres.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.p: Good day maister Pisaro.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Maister Moore, marry with all my heart good morrow sir; What newes? What newes?

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.p: This Marchant heere my friend, would speake with you.

sp.speaker: Tower.
sp.l: Sir, this iolly South-west wind with gentle blast,
Hath driuen home our long expected Shippes,
All laden with the wealth of ample Spaine,
And but a day is past since they ariude
Safely at Plimmouth, where they yet abide.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Thankes is too small a guerdon for such newes.
How like you this Newes friends? Maister Vandalle,
Heer's somewhat towards for my Daughters Dowrie:
Heer's somewhat more then we did yet expect.

sp.speaker: Tower.
sp.l: But heare you sir, my businesse is not done;
From these same Shippes I did receiue these lines,
And there inclosde this same Bill of exchange,
To pay at sight; if so you please accept it.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Accept it, why? What sir should I accept,
Haue you receiued Letters, and not I?
Where is this lazie villaine, this slow Poast:
What, brings he euery man his Letters home,
And makes mee no bodie; does hee, does hee?
I would not haue you bring me counterfeit;
And if you doe, assure you I shall smell it:
I know my Factors writing well enough.

sp.speaker: Tower.
sp.l: You doe sir; then see your Factors writing:
I scorne as much as you, to counterfeite,

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Tis well you doe sir.
What Maister Walgraue, and my other frindes:
You are growne strangers to Pisaros house,
I pray make bold with me.

sp.speaker: Walsg.
sp.l: I, with your Daughters
You may be sworne, weele be as bold as may be.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Would you haue ought with me, I pray now speak.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Sir, I thinke you vnderstand our sute,
By the repayring we haue had to you:
Gentlemen you know, must want no Coyne,
Nor are they slaues vnto it, when they haue:
You may perceiue our minds; What say you to't?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Gentlemen all, I loue you all:
Which more to manifest, this after noone
Betweene the howers of two and three repaire to mee;
And were it halfe the substance that I haue,
Whilst it is mine, tis yours to commaunde.
But Gentlemen, as I haue regard to you,
So doe I wish you'll haue respect to mee:
You know that all of vs are mortall men,
Subiect to change and mutabilitie;
You may, or I may, soone pitch ore the Pearch,
Or so, or so, haue contrary crosses:
Wherefore I deeme but meere equitie,
That some thing may betwixt vs be to shew.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: M. Pisaro, within this two months without faile,
We will repay.

sp.speaker: Browne.
sp.p: God saue you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Gentlemen.
sp.p: Good morrow sin.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: What M. Browne, the onely man I wisht for,
Does your price fall? what shall I haue these Cloathes?
For I would ship them straight away for Stoade:
I doe wish you my Mony fore another.

sp.speaker: Brow.
sp.p: Fayth you know my price sir, if you haue them.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: You are to deare in sadnesse, maister Heigham:
You were about to say somewhat, pray proceede.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Then this it was: those Landes that are not morgag'd

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: God blesse your worship.

sp.speaker: Pisaro.
sp.p: I must craue pardon; Oh sirra, are you come?

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Hoyda, hoyda; Whats the matter now;
Sure, yonder fellow will be torne in peeces.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Whats hee, sweete youths; that so they flocke about:
What old Pisaro tainted with this madnesse?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Vpon my life, tis some body bringes newes;
The Courte breakes vp, and wee shall know their Counsell:
Looke, looke, how busely they fall to reading.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: I am the last, you should haue kept it still:
Well, we shall see what newes you bring with you;
sp.p: Our duty premised, and we haue sent vnto your worship Sacke, siuill Oyles, Pepper, Barbery sugar, and such other commodities as we thought most requisite, we wanted mony therefore we are fayne to take vp 200. l. of Maister Towersons man, which by a bill of Exchange sent to him, we would request your worship pay accordingly. You shall commaund sir, you shall commaunde sir, The newes here is, that the English shipes, the Fortune, your shipe, the aduenture and good lucke of London coasting along by Italy Towards Turky, were set vpon by to Spanish-galleis, what became of them we know not, but doubt much by reason of the weathers calmnesse.

sp.speaker: Pisa
sp.l: How ist six to one the weather calme,
Now afore God who would not doubt their safety,
A plague vpon these Spanish-galli Pirattes,
Roaring Caribdis, or deuowring Scilla,
Were halfe such terrour to the anticke world,
As these same anticke Villaines now of late,
Haue made the Straights twixt Spaine and Barbary.

sp.speaker: Tower
sp.p: Now sir, what doth your Factors letters say?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Marrie he saith, these witlesse lucklesse doults,
Haue met, and are beset with Spanish Gallies,
As they did saile along by Italy:
What a bots made the dolts neere Italy,
Could they not keepe the coast of Barbary,
Or hauing past it, gone for Tripoly,
Beeing on the other side of Sicily,
As neere, as where they were vnto the Straights:
For by the Gloabe, both Tripoly and it,
Lie from the Straights some twentie fiue degrees;
And each degree makes three-score english miles?

sp.speaker: Tower.
sp.p: Very true sir: But it makes nothing to my Bill of exchange: this dealing fits not one of your account.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: And what fits yours? a prating wrangling toung,
A womans ceaselesse and incessant babling,
That sees the world turnd topsey turuie with me;
Yet hath not so much witte to stay a while,
Till I bemone my late excessiue losse.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: S'wounds tis dinner time, Ile stay no longer:
Harke you a word sir.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: I tell you sir, it would haue made you whine
Worse then if shooles of lucklesse croking Rauens,
Had ceasd on you to feed their famisht paunches:
Had you heard newes of such a rauenous rout,
Ready to cease on halfe the wealth you haue.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Sbloud you might haue kept at home & be hangd,
What a pox care I.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: God saue your worship, a little mony and so forth.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: But men are sencelesse now of others woe,
This stony age is growne so stony harted,
That none respects their neighbours miseries,
I wish (as Poets doe) that Saturnes times
The long out worne world weare in vse againe,
That men might sayle without impediment.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: I marry sir that were a merry world indeede, I would hope to gette more mony of your worship in one quarter of a yeare, then I can doe now in a whole twelue-moneth.

sp.speaker: Balsa.
sp.l: Maister Pisaro how I haue runne about,
How I haue toyld to day to finde you out,
At home, abroade, at this mans house, at that,
Why I was here an hower agoe and more,
Where I was tould you were, but could not finde you.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Fayth sir I was here but was driuen home,
Heres such a common hant of Crack-rope boyes,
That what for feare to haue m'apparell spoyld,
Or my Ruffes durted, or Eyes strucke out:
I dare not walke where people doe expect mee:
Well, things (I thinke) might be better lookt vnto,
And such Coyne to, which is bestowde on Knaues,
Which should, but doe not see things be reformd,
Might be imployde to many better vses:
But what of beardlesse Boyes, or such like trash;
The Spanish Gallies: Oh, a vengeance on them.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: Masse, this man hath the lucke on't, I thinke I can scarce euer come to him for money, but this a vengeance on, and that a vengeance on't, doth so trouble him, that I can get no Coyne: Well, a vengeance on't for my part; for he shall fetch the next Letters him selfe.

sp.speaker: Browne.
sp.p: I prethee, when thinkst thou the Ships will be come about from Plimmouth?

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: Next weeke, sir.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Came you sir from Spaine lately?

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: I sir; Why aske you that?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: Marry sir, thou seemes to haue bin in the hot countries, thy face looks so like a peece of rusty Bacon: had thy Host at Plimmoth meat enough in the house, when thou wert there?

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: What though he had not sir? but he had, how then?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.p: Marry thanke God for it; for otherwise, he would doubtles haue Cut thee out in Rashers to haue eaten thee; thou look'st as thou weart through broyld already.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: You haue sayd sir; but I am no meare for his moing, nor yours neither: If I had you in place where, you should find me tough enough in disgestion, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Walgr,
sp.p: What will you swagger sirra, will yee swagger?

sp.speaker: Brow.
sp.p: I beseech you Sir, hold your hand; Gette home yee patch, cannot you suffer Gentlemen Iest with you?

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: Ide teach him a Gentle tricke and I had him of the burse; but Ile watch him a good turne I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: Assure yee maister Towerson, I cannot blame him,
I warrant you it is no easie losse;
How thinke you maister Stranger? by my fayth sir,
Ther's twentie Marchants will be sorry for it,
That shall be partners with him in his losse.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Why sir, whats the matter.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: The Spanish-gallies haue besette our shippes,
That lately were bound out for Siria.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.p: What not? I promise you I am sorry for it.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: What an old Asse is this to keepe vs here:
Maister Pisaro, pray dispatch vs hence.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Maister Vandalle I confesse I wronge you;
But Ile but talke a word or two with him, and straight turne to you.
Ah sir, and how then y faith?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Turne to vs, turne to the Gallowes if you will,

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Tis Midsomer-Moone with him: let him alone,
He call's Ned Walgraue, Maister Vandalle.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: Let it be shrouetide, Ile not stay an ynche maister Pisaro.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: What should you feare: ende as I haue vow'd before,
So now againe; my Daughters shalbe yours:
And therefore I beseech you and your friendes,
Deferre your businesse till Dinner time;
And what youl say, keepe it for table talke.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Marrie and shall; a right good motion:
Sirrs, old Pisaro is growne kind of late,
And in pure loue, hath bid vs home to dinner.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Good newes in truth: But wherfore art thou sad?

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: For feare the slaue ere it be dinner time,
Remembring what he did, recall his word:
For by his idle speaches, you may sweare,
His heart was not confederat with his tongue.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Tut neuer doubt, keepe stomacks till anone,
And then we shall haue cates to feede vpon.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Well sir, since things doe fall so crossly out,
I must dispose my selfe to patience:
But for your businesse, doe you assure your selfe,
At my repayring home from the Exchange,
Ile set a helping hand vnto the same.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Bon iurno signeour Padre, why be de malancollie so much, and graue in you a: wat Newes make you looke so naught?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Naught is too good an epithite by much,
For to distinguish such contrariousnesse:
Hath not swift Fame told you our slow sailde Shippes
Haue been ore-taken by the swift saile Gallies,
And all my cared-for goods within the lurch
Of that same Catterpiller brood of Spaine.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Signor si, how de Spaniola haue almost tacke de Ship dat go for Turkie: my Pader, harke you me on word, I haue receiue vnlettre lettre from my Factor de Vennise, dat after vn piculo battalion, for vn halfe howre de come a Winde fra de North, & de Sea go tumble here, & tumble dare, dat make de Gallies run away for feare be almost drownde.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: How sir; did the Winde rise at North, and Seas waxe rough: and were the Gallies therefore glad to fly?

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.p: Signior si, & de Ship go drite on de Iscola de Candy.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Wert thou not my Aluaro my beloued,
One whom I know does dearely count of mee,
Much should I doubt me that some scoffing lacke,
Had sent thee in the middest of all my griefes,
To tell a feigned tale of happy lucke.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Wil you no beleuue me? see dare dan, see de lettre.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: What is this world? or what this state of man,
How in a moment curst, in a trice blest?
But euen now my happie state gan fade,
And now againe, my state is happie made,
My Goods all safe, my Ships all scapt away,
And none to bring me newes of such good lucke,
But whom the Heauens haue markt to be my Sonne:
Were I a Lord as great as Alexander,
None should more willingly be made mine Heyre
Then thee thou golden tongue, thou good-newes teller
Ioy stops my mouth.

sp.speaker: Balsa.
sp.l: M. Pisaro, the day is late, the Bell doth ring:
Wilt please you hasten to performe this businesse?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: What businesse sir? Gods mee, I cry you mercie:
Doe it, yes sir, you shall commaund me more.

sp.speaker: Tower.
sp.l: But sir, What doe you meane, doe you intend
To pay this Bill, or else to palter with mee?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Marry God sheild, that I should palter with you:
I doe accept it, and come when you please;
You shall haue money, you shall haue your money due.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: I beseech your worship to consider mee.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Oh, you cannot cogge: Goe to, take that,
Pray for my life: pray that I haue good lucke,
And thou shalt see, I will not be thy worst maister.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: Marry God blesse your Worship; I came in happy time: What, a French crowne? sure hee knowes not what he does: Well, Ile begon, least he remember himselfe, and take it from me againe.

sp.speaker: Pisa
sp.l: Come on my lads, M. Vandalle, sweet sonne Aluaro:
Come don Balsaro, lets be iogging home
Bir laken sirs, I thinke tis one a clocke.

div.stage: Extt Pisaro, Balsaro, Aluaro, Delion, and Vandalle.

sp.speaker: Brow.
sp.l: Come M. Moore, th'Exchange is waxen thin,
I thinke it best we get vs home to dinner.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: I know that I am lookt for long ere this:
Come maister Towerson, let's walke along.

div.stage: Exit Moore, Browne, Towerson, Strangers, & Marchant.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: And if you be so hot vpon your dinner,
Your best way is, to haste Pisaro on,
For he is cold enough, and slow enough;
He hath so late digested such cold newes.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: Mary and shall: Heare you maister Pisaro.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Many Pisaros heere: Why how now Ned;
Where is your Matt your welcome, and good cheare?

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: Swounds, lets follow him; why stay we heere?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Nay prethee Ned Walg. lets bethinke our selues,
There's no such haste, we may come time enough:
At first Pisaro bade vs come to him
Twixt two or three a clocke at after noone?
Then was he old Pisaro: but since then,
What with his griefe for losse, and ioy for finding,
Hee quite forgat himselfe, when he did bid vs,
And afterward forgat, that he had bade vs.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: I care not, I remember't well enough:
Hee bade vs home; and I will goe, that's flat,
To teach him better witte another time.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Heer'le be a gallant iest, when we come there,
To see how maz'd the greedie chuffe will looke
Vpon the nations, sects, and factions,
That now haue borne him company to dinner:
But harke you, lets not goe to vexe the man;
Prethee sweet Ned lets tarry, doe not goe.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Not goe? indeed you may doe what you please;
Ile goe, that's flat: nay, I am gon alreadie,
Stay you two, and consider further of it.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Nay all will goe, if one: I prethee stay;
Thou'rt such a rash and giddie headed youth,
Each Stone's a Thorne: Hoyda, he skips for haste;
Young Haruie did but iest; I know heele goe.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Nay, he may chuse for mee: But if he will,
Why does he not? why stands he prating still?
If youle goe, come: if not, fare-well?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Hier a Poast-horse for him (gentle Francke)
Heer's haste, and more haste then a hastie Pudding:
You mad-man, mad-cap, wild-oates; we are for you,
It bootes not stay, when you intend to goe.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: Come away then.

div.stage: Enter Pisaro, Aluaro, Delion, and Vandalle.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: A thousand welcomes friendes: Monsier Delion,
Ten thousand Ben-venues vnto your selfe.
Signior Aluaro, Maister Vandalle;
Proude am I, that my roofe containes such Friends.
Why Mall, Larentia, Matth; Where be these Girles?
Liuely my Girles, and bid these Strangers welcome;
They are my friends, your friends, and our wel-willers:
You cannot tell what good you may haue on them.
Gods mee, Why stirre you not? Harke in your eare,
These be the men the choyse of many millions,
That I your carefull Father haue prouided
To be your Husbands: therefore bid them welcome.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Nay by my troth, tis not the guyse of maydes,
To giue a slauering Salute to men: aside,
If these sweete youths haue not the witte to doe it,
Wee haue the honestie to let them stand.

sp.speaker: Vanda.
sp.p: Gods sekerlin, dats vn-fra meskin, Monsieur Delion dare de Grote freisler, dare wode ic zene, tis vn-fra Daughter, dare heb ic so long loude, dare Heb my desire so long gewest.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Ah Venice, Roma, Italia, Frauncia, Anglitera, nor all dis orbe can shew so much belliza, veremante de secunda, Madonade granda bewtie.

sp.speaker: Delio
sp.p: Certes me dincke de mine depeteta de little Angloise, de me Matresse Pisaro is vn nette, vn becues, vn fra, et vn tendra Damosella.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: What Stocks, what stones, what senceles Truncks be these?
When as I bid you speake, you hold your tongue:
When I bid peace, then can you prate, and chat,
And gossip: But goe too, speake and bid welcome;
Or (as I liue) you were as good you did.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: I cannot tell what Language I should speake:
Yf I speake English (as I can none other)
They cannot vnderstand mee, nor my welcome.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Bella Madona, dare is no language so dulce; dulce, dat is sweete, as de language, dat you shall speake, and de vell come dat you sal say, sal be well know perfaytemente.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: Pray sir, What is all this in English?

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: De vsa sal vell teash you vat dat is; and if you sal please, I will teash you to parler Italiano.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: And that mee thinkes sir, not without need:
And with Italian, to a Childes obedience,
With such desire to seeke to please their Parents,
As others farre more vertuous then them selues,
Doe dayly striue to doe: But tis no matter,
Ile shortly pull your haughtie stomacks downe:
Ile teach you vrge your Father; make you runne,
When I bid runne: and speake, when I bid speake:
What greater crosse can carefull parents haue knock within
Then carelesse Children. Stirre and see who knocks?

sp.speaker: Walgr.
sp.p: Good morrow to my good Mistris Mathea.

sp.speaker: Mathe.
sp.p: As good a morrow, to the morrow giuer.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: A murren, what make these? What do they heere?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: You see maister Pisaro, we are bold guestes,
You could haue bid no surer men then wee.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Harke you Gentlemen; I did expect you
At after noone, not before two a clocke.

sp.speaker: Haru,
sp.p: Why sir, if you please, you shall haue vs heere at two a clocke, at three a clocke, at foure a clock; nay till to morrow this time: yet I assure you, sir, wee came not to your house without inuiting.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Why Gentlemen, I pray who bade you now?
Who euer did it, sure hath done you wrong:
For scarcely could you come to worser cheare.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: It was your owne selfe bade vs to your cheare,
When you were busie with Balsaro talking;
You bade vs cease our suites till dinner time,
And then to vse it for our table talke:
And wee I warrant you, are as sure as Steele.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: A murren on your selues, and surenes too:
How am I crost: Gods mee, what shall I doe,
This was that ill newes of the Spanish Pirats,
That so disturb'd mee: well, I must dissemble,
And bid them welcome; but for my Daughters
Ile send them hence, they shall not stand and prate.
Well my Maisters, Gentlemen, and Friends,
Though vnexpected, yet most heartily welcome;
(Welcome with a vengeance) but for your cheare,
That will be small: yet too too much for you.
Mall, in and get things readie.
Laurentia, bid Maudlin lay the Cloth, take vp the Meate:
Looke how she stirres; you sullen Elfe, you Callet,
Is this the haste you make?

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Signor Pisaro, ne soiat so malcontento de Gentlewoman your filigola did parler but a litella to, de gentle homa y our graunde amico.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: But that graunde amico, is your graunde inimico:
One, if they be suffred to parlar,
Will poll you, I and pill you of your Wife:
They loue togeather: and the other two,
Loues her two Sisters: but tis onely you
Shall crop the flower, that they esteeme so much.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Do dey so; vell let me lone, sal see me giue dem de such graund mocke, sal be shame of dem seluves.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Doe sir, I pray you doe; set lustily vpon them,
And Ile be ready still to second you.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: But Matt, art thou so mad as to turne French?

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Yes marry when two Sundayes come together;
Thinke you Ile learne to speake this gibberidge,
Or the Pigges language? Why, if I fall sicke,
Theyle say, the French (et-cetera) infected mee.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Why how now Minion; what, is this your seruice?
Your other Sisters busie are imployde,
And you stande idle: get you in, or.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Yf you chide her, chide me (M. Pisaro:
For but for mee, she had gon in long since.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: I thinke she had: for we are sprights to scare her;
But er't be long, Ile driue that humor from her.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Signor, me thincks you soud no macke de wen she so hardee, so disobedient to de padre as ditt madona Matt.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: Signor, me thinkes you should learne to speake, before you should be so foole-hardy, as to woe such a Mayden as that Madona Matt?

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Warrent you Monsieur, he sal parle wen you sal stande out the doure.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.p: Harke you Monsieur, you would wish your selfe halfe hang'd, you were as sure to be let in as hee.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Macke no doubt de signor Alua. sal do vel enough

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: perhaps so: but me thinks your best way were to ship your selfe for Stoad, and there to batter your selfe for a commodity; for I can tell you, you are here out of liking.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: The worst perhappes dislike him, but the best esteeme him best.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.p: But by your patience sir, mee thinks none should know better who's Lord, then the Lady.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Den de Lady, vat Lady?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.p: Marry sir, the Lady let her alone: one that meanes to let you alone for feare of trouble.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Euery man as he may: yet sometimes the blinde may katch a Hare.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: I sir, but he will first eate many a Fly:
You know it must be a wonder, if a Crab catch a Fowle.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Maer hortens; if he & ic & monsier Delion be de Crab, we sal kash de Fowle wel genough, I warrent you.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: I, and the Foole well enough I warrant you;
And much good may it doe yee.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Mee dincke such a piculo man as you be, sal haue no de such grande lucke madere.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Non da Monsieur, and he be so granda amorous op de Damosella, he sal haue Mawdlyn de witt Wenshe in de Kichine by maiter Pisaros leaue.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: By M. Pisaros leaue, Monsieur Ile mumble you, except you learne to know, whom you speake to: I tell thee Francois, Ile haue (maugre thy teeth) her that shall make thee gnash thy teeth to want.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Yet a man may want of his will, and bate an Ace of his wish: But Gentlemen, euery man as his lucke serues, and so agree wee; I would not haue you fall out in my house: Come, come, all this was in iest, now lets too't in earnest; I meane with our teeth, and try who's the best Trencher-man.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p:
Ah sirra, now I know, what manner of thing Powles is; I did so marle afore what it was out of all count: For my maister would say, Would I had Powles full of Gold. My young Mistresses, and Grimkin our Taylor, would wish they had Powles full of Needles: I, one askt my maister halfe a yard of Freeze to make me a Coate and
hee cride whoope holly-day, it was big enough to make Powles a Night-gowne. I haue been told, that Duke Humfrie dwelles here, and that he keeps open house, and that a braue sort of Cammileres dine with him euery day; now if I could see any vision in the world towards dinner, I would set in a foote: But the best is, a the auncient English romaine Orator saith, So-lame-men, Misers, Howsewiues, and so foorth: the best is, that I haue great store of companie that doe nothing but goe vp and downe, and goe vp and downe, and make a grumbling togeather, that the meate is so long making readie: Well, if I could meete this scuruie Frenchman, they should stay mee, for I would be gone home.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: I beseech you Monsieur, giue mee audience.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: What would you haue? What should I giue you?

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: Pardon, sir mine vnciuill and presumptuous intrusion, who indeauour nothing lesse, then to prouoke or exasperat you against mee.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: They say, a word to the Wise is enough: so by this litle French that he speakes, I see hee is the very man I seeke for: Sir, I pray what is your name?

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: I am nominated Monsieur Le Mouche, and rest at your bon seruice.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: I vnderstand him partly; yea, and partly nay: Can you speake French? Content pore vous monsieur Madomo.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: If I could not sir, I should ill vnderstand you: you speake the best French that euer trode vpon Shoe of Leather.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Nay, I can speake more Languages then that: This is Italian, is it not? Nella slurde Curtezana.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: Yes sir, and you speake it like a very Naturall.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: I beleeue you well: now for Dutch:
Ducky de doe watt heb yee ge brought.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: I pray stop your mouth, for I neuer heard such Dutch before brocht.

sp.speaker: Frsc.
sp.p: Nay I thinke you haue not met with no pezant: Heare you M. Mouse, (so your name is I take it) I haue considered of your learning in these aforesaid Languages, and find you reasonable: So, so, now this is the matter; Can you take the ease to teach these Tongues to two or three Gentlewomen of mine acquaintance, and I will see you paide for your labour.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: Yes sir, and that most willingly.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Why then M. Mouse, to their vse, I entertaine yee, which had not been but for the troubles of the world, that I my selfe haue no leasure to shew my skill: Well sir, if youle please to walke with me, Ile bring you to them.

sp.speaker: Lauren.
sp.l: Sit till dinners done; not I, I sweare:
Shall I stay? till he belch into mine eares
Those rusticke Phrases, and those Dutch French tearmes,
Stammering halfe Sentences dogbolt Elloquence:
And when he hath no loue for-sooth, why then
Hee tels me Cloth is deare at Anwerpe, and the men
Of Amsterdam haue lately made a law,
That none but Dutch as hee, may trafficke there:
Then standes he still and studies what to say;
And after some halfe houre, because the Asse
Hopes (as he thinkes) I shall not contradict him.
Hee tels me that my Father brought him to me,
And that I must performe my Fathers will.
Well good-man Goose-cap, when thou woest againe,
Thou shalt haue simple ease, for thy Loues paine.

sp.speaker: Mathe.
sp.l: Alas poore Wench, I sorrow for thy hap,
To see how thou art clog'd with such a Dunce:
Forsooth my Sire hath fitted me farre better,
My Frenchman comes vpon me with the Sa, sa, sa;
Sweete Madam pardone moye I pray:
And then out goes his Hand, downe goes his Head,
Swallowes his Spittle, frissles his Beard; and then to mee:
Pardone moy mistresse Mathea,
If I be bold, to macke so bold met you,
Thinke it go will dat spurres me dus vp yow.
Dan cast neit off so good ande true Louer,
Madama celestura de la, (I know not what)
Doe oft pray to God dat me woud loue her:
And then hee reckons a catalogue of names
of such as loue him, and yet cannot get him.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Nay, but your Monsieur's but a Mouse in cheese,
Compard with my Signor; hee can tell
Of Lady Venus, and her Sonne blind Cupid:
Of the faire Scilla that was lou'd of Glaucus,
And yet scornd Glaucus, and yet lou'd King Minos;
Yet Minos hated her, and yet she holp'd him;
And yet he scorn'd her, yet she kild her Father
To doe her good; yet he could not abide her:
Nay, hele be bawdy too in his discourse;
And when he is so, he will take my Hand,
And tickle the Palme, wincke with his one Eye,
Gape with his Mouth, and

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: And, hold thy tongue I prethee: here's my father.

div.stage: Enter Pisaro, Aluaro, Vandalle, Delion, Haruie, Walgraue, and Heigham.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Vnmannerly, vntaught, vnnurtred Girles,
Doe I bring Gentlemen, my very friends
To feast with mee, to reuell at my House,
That their good likings, may be set on you,
And you like misbehaud and sullen Girles,
Turne tayle to such, as may aduance your states:
I shall remembert, when you thinke I doe not.
I am sorrie Gentlemen, your cheare's no better;
But what did want at Board, excuse me for,
And you shall haue amendes be made in Bed.
To them friends, to them; they are none but yours:
For you I bred them, for you brought them vp:
For you I kept them, and you shall haue them:
I hate all others that resort to them:
Then rouse your bloods, be bold with what's your owne:
For I and mine (my friends) be yours, or none.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: God-gee god-morrow sir, I haue brought you M. Mouse here to teach my young Mistresses: I assure you (for-sooth) he is a braue Frenchman.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Welcome friend, welcome: my man (I thinke)
Hath at the full, resolu'd thee of my will.
Monsieur Delion, I pray question him:
I tell you sir, tis onely for your sake,
That I doe meane to entertaine this fellow,

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: A bots of all ill lucke, how came these heere?
Now am I posde except the Wenches helpe mee:
I haue no French to flap them in the mouth,

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: To see the lucke of a good fellow, poore Anthony
Could nere haue sorted out a worser time:
Now will the packe of all our sly deuises
Be quite layde ope, as one vndoes an Oyster:
Francke, Heigham, and mad Ned, fall to your muses,
To helpe poore Anthony now at a pinch,
Or all our market will be spoyld and marde.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: Tut man, let vs alone, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Monsieur, Vous estes tresbien venu, de quell pais estes vous.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: Vous, thats you: sure he saies, how do men call you Monsieur le Mouche?

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Sister, helpe sister; that's honest Anthonie,
And he answers, your woer cuius contrarium.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p:
Monsieur, Vous n'entens pas, Je ne demaunde puit,
vostre nom?

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.p: Monsieur Delion, he that made your Shooes, made them not in fashion: they should haue been cut square at the toe.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Madame, my Sho met de square toe, vat be dat?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Why sauce-box; how now you vnreuerent mincks
Why? in whose Stable hast thou been brought vp,
To interrupt a man in midst of speach?
Monsieur Delion, disquiet not your selfe,
But as you haue begun, I pray proceed
To question with this Countriman of yours.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Dat me sal doe tres beien, but de bella Madona de iune Gentlewoman do monstre some singe of amour to speake lot me, epurce monsieur, mee sal say but two tree fowre fiue word to dir francois: or sus Monsieur Le mouche en quelle partie de Fraunce esties vous ne?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.p: Fraunce.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Ned.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Sbloud, let mee come.
Maister Pisaro, we haue occasion of affaires,
Which calles vs hence with speed; wherefore I pray
Deferre this businesse till some fitter time,
And to performe what at the Exchange we spoke of.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: A blessing on that tongue, saith Anthony.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Yes marry Gentlemen, I will, I will.
Aluaro to your taske, fall to your taske,
Ile beare away those three, who being heere,
Would set my Daughters on a merry pin:
Then chearely try your luckes; but speake, and speed,
For you alone (say I) shall doe the deed.

div.stage: Exeunt Pisaro, Haruy, Walgraue, and Higham.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Heare you M. Mouse, did you dine to day at Paules with the rest of the Gentlemen there?

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: No sir, I am yet vndined.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p:
Mee thinkes you should haue a reasonable good
stomacke then by this time, as for me I can sell nothinge within me from my mouth to my Cod-peece but all Emptie, wherefore I thinke a peece of wisdome to goe in and see what Maudelin hath prouided for our Dinner maister Mouse will you goe in?

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: With as good a stomacke and desire as your selfe.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Lett's passe in then

sp.speaker: Vanda.
sp.p: Han seg you Dochtor, vor vat cause, voer why bede also much grooterlie strange, Ic seg you wat, if datt ghy speake to me, is datt ghy loue me.

sp.speaker: Lauren.
sp.p: Ist that I care not for you, ist that your breath stinckes, if that your breath stinckes not, you must learne sweeter English or I shall neuer vnderstand your suite.

sp.speaker: Delion.
sp.p: Pardone moy Madame.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.p: With all my heart so you offend no more.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Is dat an offence to be amorous di one belle Gentleawoman.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.p: I sir see your Belle Gentle-woman cannot be amorous of you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Then if I were as that belle Gentlewomans louer,
I would trouble her no further, nor be amorous any longer.

sp.speaker: Aluar.
sp.p: Madona yet de Belleza of de face beutie deforme of all de Corpo may be such datt no perriculo, nor all de mal shaunce, can make him leaue hir dulce visage.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: But signor Aluaro if the periculo or mal shaunce were sutch, that she should loue and liue with an other, then the dulce visage must be lefte in spite of the louers teeth, whilst he may whine at his owne ill fortune.

sp.speaker: Vanda.
sp.p: Datts waer matresse, for it is vntrue saying, dey wint he taught dey verleift lie scrat sin gatt.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.p: And I thinke to are like to scratch there but neuer to claw any of my Sisters loue away.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p:
Dan sal your sistree do gainst her vaders will,
or your vader segt dat ick sal heb her vor mine wife.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: I thinke not so sir, for I neuer heard him say so, but Ile goe in and aske him if his meaning be so.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: Harke sister signor Aluaro sayth, that I am the fayrest of all vs three,

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Beleeue him not for heele tell any lie.
If so he thinkes thou mayst be pleasd thereby,
Come goe with me and neere stand pratinge here,
I haue a iest to tell thee in thine eare,
Shall make you laugh: come let your signor stand,
I know there's not a Wench in all this Towne,
Scoffes at him more, or loues him lesse then thou.
Maister Vandalle, as much I say for you;
If needes you marry with an English Lasse,
Woe her in English, or sheele call you Asse.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Tut that's a French cogge; sure I thinke,
There's nere a Wench in Fraunce not halfe so fond,
To woe and sue so for your Mounsership.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Par may foy Madame, she does tincke dare is no Wenche so dure as you: for de Fillee was cree dulce, tendre, and amarous for me to loue hir; now me tincke dat I being such a fine man, you should loua me.

sp.speaker: Mathe.
sp.p: So thinke not I, sir.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: But so tincke esh oder Damosellas.

sp.speaker: Mathe.
sp.l: Nay Ile lay my loue to your commaunde,
That my Sisters thinke not so: How say you sister Mall?
Why how now Gentlemen, is this your talke?
What beaten in plaine field: where be your Maydes?
Nay then I see their louing humor fades,
And they resigne their intrest vp to mee;
And yet I cannot serue for all you three:
But least two should be madd, that I loue one,
You shall be all alike, and Ile loue none:
The world is scant, when so many Iacke Dawes,
Houer about one Coarse with greedy pawes:
Yf needes youle haue me stay till I am dead,
Carrion for Crowes, Mathea for her Ned:
And so farewell, wee Sisters doe agree,
To haue our willes, but nere to haue you three.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Madama attendez, Madama: is she alle? doe she mockque de nows in such sort?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Oh de pestilence, noe if datick can neite dese Englese spreake vel, it shal hir Fader seg how dit is to passe gecomen.

sp.speaker: Aluar.
sp.p: Ne parlate, see here signors de Fader.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Now Friends, now Gentlemen, how speedes your worke; haue you not found them shrewd vnhappy girls?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Mester Pisaro, de Dochter maistris Laurentia calle me de Dyel, den Asse, for that ic can neit englesh spreken.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Ande dat we sal no parler, dat we sal no hauar den for de wiue.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Are they so lusty? Dare they be so proude?
Well, I shall find a time to meete with them:
In the meane season, pray frequent my house.
Ho now sirra, whither are you running?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: About a little tiny businesse.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: What businesse, Asse?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Indeed I was not sent to you: and yet I was sent after the three Gen-men that din'd here, to bid them come to our house at ten a clocke at night, when you were abed.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Ha, what is this? Can this be true?
What, art thou sure the Wenches bade them come?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: So they said, vnlesse their mindes be changed since: for a Woman is like a Weather-cocke they say, & I am sure of no more then I am certaine of: but Ile go in and bid them send you word, whether they shall come or no.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: No sirra, stay you heere; but one word more: Did they appoint than come one by one, or else al together?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Altogether: Lord that such a young man as you should haue no more witt: why if they should come together, one could not make rome for them; but comming one by one, theyle stand there if there were twenty of them.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: How this newes glads me, and reuiues my soule: How say you sirs, what will you haue a iest worth the telling; nay worth the acting: I haue it Gentlemen, I haue it Friends.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Signor Pisaro, I prey de gratia watte maneire sal we haue? wat will the parler? wat bon doe you know Signor Pisaro, dicheti noi signor Pisaro.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Oh that youth so sweete, so soone should turne to age; were I as you, why this were sport alone for me to doe.
sp.l: Harke yee, harke yee; heere my man,
Saith, that the Girles haue sent for Maister Heigham
And his two friends; I know they loue them dear,
And therefore wish them late at night be heere
To reuell with them: Will you haue a iest,
To worke my will, and giue your longings rest:
Why then M. Vandalle, and you two,
Shall soone at midnight come, as they should doe,
And court the Wenches; and to be vnknowne,
And taken for the men, whom they alone
So much affect; each one shall change his name:
Maister Vandalle, you shall take Heigham, and you
Younge Haruie, and monsieur Delion Ned,
And vnder shadowes be of substance sped:
How like you this deuice? how thinke you of it?

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Oh de braue de galliarde deuise: me sal come by de nite and contier faire de Anglois Gentlehomes dictenous ainsi monsieur Pisaro.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: You are in the right sir.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: And I sall name me de signor Haruy, ende monsieur Delion sall be de piculo signor Ned, ende when madona Laurentia sall say, who be dare? mister Vandalle sall say, Oh my sout Laide, hier be your loue Mestro Heigham: Is no dis de brauissime, maister Vandalle?

sp.speaker: Vanda.
sp.l: Slact vp den tromele, van ick sall come
Vp to de camerken, wan my new Wincken
Slact vp den tromele, van ick sall come.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, maister Vandalle,
I trow you will be merrie soone at night,
When you shall doe in deed, what now you hope of.

sp.speaker: Vanda.
sp.p: I sall v seg vader, Ick sall tesh your Daughter such a ting, make her laugh too.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Well my Sonnes all, (for so I count you shall)
What we haue heere deuis'd, prouide me for:
But aboue all, doe not (I pray) forget
To come but one by one, as they did wish.

sp.speaker: Vanda.
sp.p: Mar hortens vader, ick veite neite de wecke to your houis, hortens sall maister Frisco your manneken come to calle de me, and bring me to v house.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Yes marry shall hee: see that you be ready,
And at the hower of eleuen sone at night:
Hie you to Bucklersburie to his Chamber,
And so direct him straight vnto my house:
My Sonne Aluaro, and monsieur Delion,
I know, doth know the way exceeding well:
Well, weele to the Rose in Barken for an hower:
And sirra Frisco, see you proue no blabbe.

div.stage: Exeunt Pisaro, Aluaro, Delion, and Vandalle.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p:
Oh monstrous, who would thinke my Maister had so much witte in his old rotten budget: and yet yfayth he is not much troubled with it neither. Why what wise man in a kingdome would sende me for the Dutch-man? Does hee thinke Ile not cousen him: Oh fine, Ile
haue the brauest sport: Oh braue, Ile haue the gallentest sport: Oh come; now if I can hold behinde, while I may laugh a while, I care not: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: Why how now Frisco, why laughest thou so hartily?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Laugh M. Mouse: Laugh, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Antho
sp.p: Laugh, why should I laugh? or why art thou so merry?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Oh maister Mouse, maister Mouse, it would make any Mouse, Ratte, Catte, or Dogge, laugh to thinke, what sport we shall haue at our house sone at night: Ile tell you, all, my young Mistresses sent me after M. Heigham and his friendes, to pray them come to our house after my old Maister was a bed: Now I went, and I went; and I runne, and I went: and whom should I meete, but my Maister and M. Pisaro and the Strangers; so my Maister very worshipfully (I must needs say) examined me whither I went now? I durst not tell him an vntruth, for feare of lying, but told him plainely and honestly mine arrande: Now who would thinke my Maister had such a monstrous plaguie witte, hee was as glad as could be; out of all scotch and notch glad, out of all count glad? and so sirra he bid the three Vplandish-men come in their steades and woe my young Mistresses: Now it made mee so laugh to thinke how they will be cousend, that I could not follow my Maister: But Ile follow him, I know he is gone to the Tauerne in his merry humor: Now if you will keepe this as secret as I haue done hitherto, wee shall haue the brauest sport soone, as can be. I must be gone, say nothing.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Well it is so:
And we will haue good sport, or it shall go hard;
This must the Wenches know, or all is marde.
Harke you Mis. Moll, Mis. Laurentia, Mis. Matt,
I haue such newes (my Girles) will make you smile.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: What be they Maister, how I long to heare it?

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: A Woman right, still longing, and with child,
For euery thing they heare, or light vpon:
Well. if you be mad Wenches, heare it now,
Now may your knaueries giue the deadliest blow
To night-walkers, eauese-droppers, or outlandish loue,
That ere was stristen.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Anthony Mowche,
Moue but the matter; tell vs but the iest,
And if you find vs slacke to execute,
Neuer giue credence, or beleeue vs more.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Then know: The Strangers your Outlandish loues,
Appoynted by your Father, comes this night
In stead of Haruie, Heigham, and young Ned,
Vnder their shaddowes to get to your bed:
For Frisco simply told him why he went:
I need not to instruct, you can conceiue,
You are not Stockes nor Stones, but haue some store
Of witte and knauerie too.

sp.speaker: Mathe.
sp.l: Anthony, thankes
Is too too small a guerdon for this newes;
You must be English: Well sir signor sowse,
Ile teach you trickes for comming to our house.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Are you so craftie, oh that night were come,
That I might heare my Dutchman how hee'd sweare
In his owne mother Language, that he loues me:
Well, if I quit him not, I here pray God,
I may lead Apes in Hell, and die a Mayde;
And that were worser to me then a hanging.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Well said old honest huddles; here's a heape
Of merrie Lasses: Well, for my selfe,
Ile hie mee to your Louers, bid them maske
With vs at night, and in some corner stay
Neere to our house, where they may make some play
Vpon your riuals, and when they are gon,
Come to your windowes.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: Doe so good Maister.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Peace, begon; for this our sport,
Some body soone will moorne.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: How fauourable Heauen and Earth is seene,
To grace the mirthfull complot that is laide,
Nights Candles burne obscure, and the pale Moone
Fauouring our drift, lyes buried in a Cloude:
I can but smile to see the simple Girles,
Hoping to haue their sweete-hearts here to night,
Tickled with extreame ioy, laugh in my face:
But when they finde, the Strangers in their steades,
Theyle change their note, and sing an other song.
Where be these Girles heere? what, to bed, to bed:
Mawdlin make fast the Dores, rake vp the Fire;
Gods me, tis nine a clocke, harke Bow-bell rings: Knocke.
Some looke downe below, and see who knockes:
And harke you Girles, settle your hearts at rest,
And full resolue you, that to morrow morne,
You must be wedd to such as I preferre;
I meane Aluaro and his other friendes:
Let me no more be troubled with your nayes.
You shall doe what Ile haue, and so resolue.
Welcome M. Moore, welcome,
What winde a-gods name driues you foorth so late?

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Fayth sir, I am come to trouble you,
My wife this present night is brought to bed.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: To bed, and what hath God sent you?

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: A iolly Girle, sir.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: And God blesse her: But what's your will sir?

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: Fayth sir, my house being full of Friends,
Such as (I thanke them) came to see my wife?
I would request you, that for this one night,
My daughter Susan might be lodged here.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Lodge in my house, welcome with all my heart,
Matt harke you, she shall lye with you,
Trust me she could not come in fitter time.
For heere you sir, to morrow in the morning.
All my three Daughters must be married,
Good maister Moore lets haue your company,
What say you sir; Welcome honest friend.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: How now sirra whats the newes with you?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Mowche heare you, stirre betimes to morrow,
For then I meane your Schollers shall be wed:
What newes, what newes man that you looke so sad,

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: Hee brings me word my wife is new falne sicke,
And that my daughter cannot come to night:
Or if she does, it will be very late.

sp.speaker: Pisa,
sp.l: Beleeue me I am then more sorry for it.
But for your daughter come she soone or late,
Some of vs will be vp to let her in,
For heere be three meanes not to sleepe to night:
Well you must be gone? commende me to your wife,
Take heede how you goe downe, the staires are bad,
Bring here a light.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: Tis well I thanke you sir.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Good night maister Moore farwell honest friend,
Come, come to bed, to bed tis nine and past,
Doe not stand prating here to make me fetch you,
But gette you to your Chambers. Exit Pisaro.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Birlady heres short worke, harke you Girles,
Will you to morrow marry with the strangers.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Y fayth sir no Ile first leape out at window,
Before Marina marry with a stranger,

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: Yes but your father sweares, you shall haue one.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Yes but his daughters, swears they shall haue none,
These horeson Canniballs, these Philistines,
These tango mongoes shall not rule Ore me,
Ile haue my will and Ned, or Ile haue none.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: How will you get him? how will you get him?
I know no other way except it be this,
That when your fathers in his soundest sleepe,
You ope the Dore and runne away with them,

sp.speaker: All sisters.
sp.p: So wee will rather then misse of them.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Tis well resolude yfayth and like your selues,
But heare you? to your Chambers presently,
Least that your father doe discry our drift, Exeunt Sisters.
Mistres Susan should come but she cannot,
Nor perhaps shall not, yet perhaps she shall,
Might not a man conceipt a prettie iest?
And make as mad a Riddle as this is,
If all thinges fadge not, as all thinges should doe,
Wee shall be sped y'fayth, Matt shall haue hue.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Wear be you mester Frisco.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Here sir, here sir, now if I could cousen him, take heede sir hers a post.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Ick be so groterly hot, datt ick swette, Oh wen sal we come dare.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Be you so hotte sir, let me carry your Cloake, I assure you it will ease you much.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Dare here, dare, tis so Darke ey can neit see.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: I, so so: now you may trauell in your Hose and Doublet: now looke I as like the Dutchman, as if I were spit out of his mouth: Ile straight home, & speake groote and broode, and toot and gibrish; and in the darke Ile haue a fling at the Wenches. Well, I say no more; farewell M. Mendall, I must goe seeke my fortune.

sp.speaker: Vanda.
sp.p:
Mester Frisco, mester Frisco, wat sal you no speak; make you de Foole? Why mester Frisco; Oh de skellum,
he be ga met de Cloake, me sal seg his mester, han mester Frisco, waer sidy mester Frisco.

sp.speaker: Haruy.
sp.l: Goes the case so well signor bottle-nose?
It may be we shall ouerreach your drift;
This is the time the Wenches sent vs word
Our bumbast Dutchman and his mates will come.
Well neat Italian, you must don my shape:
Play your part well, or I may haps pay you.
What, speechlesse Ned? fayth whereon musest thou?
Tis on your French coriuall, for my life:
Hee come ete vostre, and so foorth,
Till he hath foysted in a Brat or two?
How then, how then?

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Swounds Ile geld him first,
Ere that insestious loszell reuell there.
Well Matt, I thinke thou knowst what Ned can doe;
Shouldst thou change Ned for Noddy, mee for him,
Thou didst not know thy losse, yfayth thou didst not.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Come leaue this idle chatte, and lets prouide
Which of vs shall be scar-crow to these Fooles,
And set them out the way?

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: Why that will I.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Then put a Sword into a mad-mans hand:
Thou art so hasty, that but crosse thy humor,
And thou't be ready crosse them ore the pates:
Therefore for this time, Ile supply the rome.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: And so we shall be sure of chatt enough;
Youle hold them with your floutes and gulles so long,
That all the night will scarcely be enough
To put in practise, what we haue deuisde:
Come, come, Ile be the man shall doe the deed.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Well, I am content to saue your longing.
But soft, where are we? Ha, heere's the house,
Come let vs take our stands: Fraunce stand you there,
And Ned and I will crosse t'other side.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Doe so: But hush, I heare one passing hither.

sp.speaker: Aluar.
sp.p: Oh de fauorable aspect of de heauen, tis so obscure, so darke, so blacke dat no mortalle creature can know de me: I pray a Dio I sal haue de reight Wench: Ah si I be recht, here be de huis of signor Pisaro, I sall haue de madona Marina, and daruor I sall knocke to de dore.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: What a pox are you mad or druncke;
What, doe you meane to breake my Glasses?

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Wat be dat Glasse? Wat druncke, wat mad?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: What Glasses sir; why my Glasses: and if you be so crancke, Ile call the Constable; you will not enter into a mans house (I hope) in spight of him?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Nor durst you be so bold as to stand there,
Yf once the Maister of the House did know it.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Is dit your Hous? be you de Signor of dis Cassa?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Signor me no signors, nor cassa me no cassas: but get you hence, or you are like to taste of the Bastinado.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Do, do, good Ferdinand, pummell the logerhead.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Is this neit the Hous of mester Pisaro?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Yes marry when? can you tell: how doe you?
I thanke you heartily, my finger in your mouth.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Wat be dat?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Marry that you are an Asse and a Logerhead,
To seeke maister Pisaros house heere.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.l: I prey de gratia, wat be dis plashe?
Wat doe ye call dit strete?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: What sir; why Leaden-hall, could you not see the foure Spoutes as you came along?

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Certenemento Leden hall, I hit my hed by de way, dare may be de voer Spouts: I prey de gratia, wish be de wey to Crochefriers?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: How, to Croched-friers? Marry you must goe along till you come to the Pumpe, and then turne on your right hand.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Signor, adio.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Farewell and be hang'd Signor:
Now for your fellow, if the Asse would come.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: By my trot me doe so mush tincke of dit Gentle-woman de fine Wenshe, dat me tincke esh houer ten day, and esh day ten yeare, till I come to her: Here be de huise of sin vader, sall alle and knocke. He knocks.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: What a bots ayle you, are you madd?
Will you runne ouer me and breake my Glasses?

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Glasses, wat Glasses? Prey is monsieur Pisaro to de mayson?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Harke Ned, there's thy substaunce

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Nay by the Masse, the substaunce's heere,
The shaddow's but an Asse.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: What Maister Pisaro?
Logerhead, heere's none of your Pisaros?

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Yes but dit is the houis of mester Pisaro.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Will not this monsieur Motley take his answer?
Ile goe and knocke the asse about the pate.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Nay by your leaue sir, but Ile hold your worship.
This sturre we should haue had, had you stood there.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Why, would it not vexe one to heare the asse,
Stand prating here of dit and dan, and den and dog?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: One of thy mettle Ned, would surely doe it:
But peace, and harke to the rest.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Doe no de fine Gentlewoman matresse Mathea dwell in dit Plashe?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: No sir, here dwels none of your fine Gantle-woman: Twere a good deed sirra, to see who you are;
sp.l: You come hither to steale my Glasses.
And then counterfeite you are going to your Queanes.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: I be deceu dis darke neight; here be no Wenshe, I be no in de right plashe: I prey Monsieur, wat be name dis Streete, and wishe be de way to Croshe-friers?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Marry this is Fanchurch-streete,
And the best way to Crotched-friers, is to follow your nose

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Vanshe, streete, how shaunce me come to Vanshe streete? vell monsieur, me must alle to Croche-friers.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Farewell fortipence, goe seeke your Signor,
I hope youle finde your selues two Dolts anone:
Hush Fredinand, I heare the last come stamping hither.

sp.speaker: Frise.
sp.p: Ha sirra, I haue left my fatte Dutchman, and runne my selfe almost out of breath too: now to my young mistresses goe I, some body cast an old shoe after me: but soft, how shall I doe to counterfeite the Dutchman, be cause I speake English so like a naturall; Tush, take you no thought for that, let me alone for Squintum squantum: soft, her's my Maisters house,

sp.speaker: High.
sp.p: Whos's there.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Whos's there, why sir here is: Nay thats too good English; Why here be de growtte Dutchman.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Then theres not onely a growte head, but an Asse also.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: What be yoo, yoo be an English Oxe to call a gentle moan Asse.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.p: Harke Ned yonders good greeting.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: But yoo, and yoo be Maister Mouse that dwell here, tell your matressa Laurentia datt her sweete harte Maister Vandall would speake with horde,

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Maister Mendall, gette you gon, least you get a broken Pate and so marre all: heres no entrance for misstres Laurentios sweete heart.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Gods sacaren watt is the luck now.
Shall not I come to my friend maister Pisar Hoose?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Yes and to maister Pisaros Shoes too, if hee or they were here.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Why my groute friend, M. Pisaro doth dwel here.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Sirra, you lye, heere dwells no body but I, that haue dwelt here this one & forty yeares, and sold Glasses.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: Lye farder, one and fifty at the least.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Hoo, hoo, hoo; do you giue the Gentleman the ly?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.p: I sir, and will giue you a licke of my Cudgell, if yee stay long and trouble the whole streete with your bawling: hence dolt, and goe seeke M. Pisaros House.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Goe seeke M. Pisaros House;
Where shall I goe seeke it?

sp.speaker: Hegh.
sp.p: Why, you shall goe seeke it where it is.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: That is here in Crodched-friers.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: How Loger-head, is Croched-friers heere?
I thought you were some such drunken Asse,
That come to seeke Croched-friers in Tower-streete:
But get you along on your left hand, and be hang'd;
You haue kept me out of my Bedd with your bangling,
A good while longer then I would haue been.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Ah, ah, How is this? Is not this Croched-friers? Tell mee, Ile hold a Crowne they gaue me so much Wine at the Tauerne, that I am druncke, and know not out.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: My Dutchman's out his Compasse & his Card;
Hee's reckning what Winde hath droue him hither:
Ile sweare hee thinkes neuer to see Pisaros.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Nay tis so, I am sure druncke: Soft let mee see, what was I about?
