Oh now I haue it, I must goe to my Maisters house and counterfeite the Dutchman, and get my young Mistresse: well, and I must turne on my left hand, for I haue forgot the way quite and cleane: Fare de well good frend, I am a simple Dutchman I.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Faire weather after you. And now my Laddes,
Haue I not plide my part as I should doe?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Twas well, twas well: But now let's cast about,
To set these Woodcocks farder from the House,
And afterwards returne vnto our Girles.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: Content, content; come, come make haste.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: I goe and turne, and dan I come to dis plashe, I can no tell watt, and sall doe I can no tell watt, turne by the Pumpe; I pumpe it faire.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Me alle, ende alle & can no come to Croche-friers.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Oh miserable Blacke-pudding, if I can tell which is the way to my Maisters house, I am a Red-herring, and no honest Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Who parlato daer?

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Who be der? who alle der?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: How's this? For my life here are the Strangers: Oh that I had the Dutchmans Hose, that I might creepe into the Pockets; they'le all three fall vpon me & beat me.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Who doe der ander?

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Amis?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Oh braue; it's no body but M. Pharoo and the Frenchman going to our House, on my life: well, Ile haue some sport with them, if the Watch hinder me not. Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Who parle der, in wat plashe, in wat streat be you?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Why sir, I can tell where I am; I am in Tower-streete: Where a Diuell be you?

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Io be here in Lede-hall.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: In Leaden-hall? I trow I shall meete with you anone: in Leaden-hall? What a simple Asse is this Frenchman. Some more of this: Where are you sir?

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Moy I be here in Vanshe-streete.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: This is excellent ynfayth, as fit as a Fiddle: I in Tower-streete, you in Leaden-hall, and the third in Fanchurch-streete; and yet all three heare one another, and all three speake togeather: either wee must be all three in Leaden-hall, or all three in Tower-streete, or all three in Fanchurch-streete; or all three Fooles.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Monsieur Gentle-home, can you well tesh de wey to Croshe-frier?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: How to Croched-friers? I, I sir, passing well if you will follow mee.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: I dat me sal monsier Gentle-home, and giue you tanks.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: And monsiur Pharo, I shall lead you such a iaunt, that you shall scarce giue me thankes for. Come sirrs follow mee: now for a durtie Puddle, the pissing Condit, or a great Post, that might turne these two from Asses to Oxen by knocking their Hornes to their Fore-heads.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Whaer be de now signor?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Euen where you will signor, for I know not:
Soft I smell: Oh pure Nose.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Wat do you smell?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: I haue the scent of London-stone as full in my nose, as Abchurch-lane of mother Walles Pasties: Sirrs feele about, I smell London-stone.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Wat be dis?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Soft let me see; feele I should say, for I cannot see: Oh lads pray for my life, for we are almost at Croched-friers.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Dats good: but watt be dis Post?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: This Post; why tis the May-pole on Iuie-bridge going to Westminster.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Ho Wesmistere, how come we tol Wesmistere?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Why on your Legges fooles, how should you goe? Soft, heere's an other: Oh now I know in deede where I am; wee are now at the fardest end of Shoredich, for this is the May-pole.

sp.speaker: Delo.
sp.p:
Sordiche; O dio, dere be some nautie tinge, some
Spirite do leade vs.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: You say true sir, for I am afeard your French spirt is vp so far alredy, that you brought me this way, because you would finde a Charme for it at the Blew Bore in the Spittle: But soft, who comes heere?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Maydes in your Smocks, looke wel to your Locks, Your Fier and your Light; and God giue you good night.

sp.speaker: Delia.
sp.p: Monsieur Gentle-home, I prey parle one, too, tree, fore, words vore vs to dis oull man.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Yes marry shall I sir. I pray honest Fellow, in what Streete be wee?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ho Frisco, whither friske you at this time of night?

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: What, Monsieur Frisco?

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Signor Frisco?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: The same, the same: Harke yee honesty, mee thinkes you might doe well to haue an M. vnder your Girdle, considering how Signor Pifaro, and this other Monsieur doe hold of mee.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh sir, I cry you mercie; pardon this fault, and Ile doe as much for you the next time.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Well, passing ouer superfluicall talke, I pray what Street is this; for it is so darke, I know not where I am?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why art thou druncke, Dost thou not know Fanchurch-streete?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: I sir, a good Fellow may sometimes be ouerseene among Friends; I was drinking with my Maister and these Gentlemen, and therefore no maruaile though I be none of the wisest at this present: But I pray thee Goodman Buttericke, bring mee to my Maisters House.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Why I will, I will, push that you are so strange now adayes: but it is an old said saw, Honors change Manners.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Good-man Buttericke will you walke afore:
Come honest Friends, will yee goe to our House?

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Ouy monsieur Frisco.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Si signor Frisco.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Oh de skellam Frisco, ic weit neit waer dat ic be, ic goe and hit my nose op dit post, and ic goe and hit my nose op danden post; Oh de villaine: Well, waer ben ic now? Haw laet syen is dut neit croshe vrier, ya seker so ist and dit M. Pisaros huis: Oh de good shaunce, well ic sall now haue de Wenshe Laurentia, mestris Laurentia.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: Who's there, Maister Haruie?

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.p: Maister Walgraue?

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Maister Heigham?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Ya my Louue, here be mester Heigham your groot frinde.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: How, Maister Heigham my grot vrinde?
Out alas, here's one of the Strangers.

sp.speaker: Lauren.
sp.p: Peace you Mammet, let's see which it is; wee may chaunce teach him a strange tricke for his learning: M. Heigham, what wind driues you to our house so late?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Oh my leif Mesken, de loue tol v be so groot, dat het bring me out my bed voor you.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.p: Ha, ha, we know the Asse by his eares; it is the Dutchman: what shall we doe with him?

sp.speaker: Laure.
sp.p: Peace, let him not know, that you are heere: M. Heigham, if you will stay awhile that I may se, if my Father be a sleepe, and Ile make meanes we may come togeather

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Dat sal ick my Loua. Is dit no well counterfett I speake so like mester Heigham as tis possible.

sp.speaker: Laure.
sp.p: Well, what shall we doe with this Lubber? (Louer I should say.)

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: What shall wee doe with him?
Why crowne him with a—

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p:
Fie Slutt: No, wele vse him clenlier; you know we haue neuer a Signe at the dore, would not the iest proue
currant, to make the Dutchman supply that want.

sp.speaker: Laure.
sp.p: Nay, the foole wil cry out, & so wake my father.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Why, then wele cut the Rope & cast him downe.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: And so iest out a hanging; let's rather draw him vp in the Basket, and so starue him to death this frosty night.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: In sadnesse, well aduisde: Sister, doe you holde him in talke, and weele prouide it whilst.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Goe to then. M. Heigham, oh sweete M Higham, doth my Father thinke that his vnkindnes can part you & poore Laurentia? No, no, I haue found a drift to bring you to my Chamber, if you haue but the heart to venter it.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Ventre, salick goe to de see, and be de see, and ore de see and in de see voer my sweete Louue.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Then you dare goe into a Basket; for I know no other meanes to inioy your companie, then so: for my Father hath the Keyes of the Dore.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Salick climb vp tot you? sal ick fly vp tot you? salick, wat segdy?

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.p: Bid him doe it Sister, wee shall see his cunning.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Oh no, so you may catch a fal. There M. Heigham, Put your selfe into that Basket, and I will draw you vp: But no words I pray you, for feare my Sister heare you.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: No, no; no word: Oh de feete Wenshe, Ick come, Ick come.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Are you ready maister Heigham?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Ia ick my sout Lady.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: Merily then my Wenches.

sp.speaker: Laur
sp.p: How heauie the Asse is: Maister Heigham, is there any in the Basket but your selfe?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Neit, neit, dare be no man.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Are you vp sir?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Neit, neit.

sp.speaker: Mari
sp.p: Nor neuer are you like to climbe more higher: Sisters, the Woodcock's caught, the Foole is cag'd.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: My sout Lady I be nuc neit vp, pul me totv.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: When can you tell; what maister Vandalle,
A wether beaten soldier an old wencher,
Thus to be ouer reach'd by three young Girles:
Ah sirra now weele bragge with Mistres Moore,
To haue as fine a Parret as she hath,
Looke sisters what a pretty foole it is:
What a greene greasie shyning Coate he hath,
An Almonde for Parret, a Rope for Parret.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: Doe you moc que me seger seger,
I sal seg your vader.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Doe and you dare, you see here is your fortune,
Disquiet not my father; if you doe,
Ile send you with a vengeance to the ground,
Well we must confesse we trouble you,
And ouer watching makes a wiseman madde,
Much more a foole, theres a Cusshon for you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: To bore you through the nose.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: To lay your head on.
Couch in your Kennell sleape and fall to rest,
And so good night for London maydes skorne still,
A Dutch-man should be seene to curbe their will.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Hort ye Daughter, hort ye¿ gods se ker kin? will ye no let me come tot you? ick bid you let me come tot you watt sal ick don, ick woud neit vor vn hundred pounde Aluaro & Delion, should see me ope dit maner, well wat sal ick don, ick mout neit cal: vor de Wenshes wil cut de rope and breake my necke; ick sal here bleauen til de morning, & dan ick sal cal to mester Pisaro, & make him shafe & shite his dauctors: Oh de skellum Frisco, Oh des cruell Hores.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Ile put the Light out, least I be espied,
For closely I haue stolne me foorth a doares,
That I might know, how my three Sonnes haue sped.
Now (afore God) my heart is passing light,
That I haue ouerreach'd the Englishmen:
Ha, ha, Maister Vandalle, many such nights
Will swage your bigg swolne bulke, and make it lancke:
When I was young; yet though my Haires be gray,
I haue a Young mans spirit to the death,
And can as nimbly trip it with a Girle,
As those which fold the spring-tide in their Beards:
Lord how the verie thought of former times,
Supples these neere dried limbes with actiuenesse:
Well, thoughts are shaddowes, sooner lost then seene,
Now to my Daughters, and their merrie night,
I hope Aluaro and his companie,
Haue read to them morrall Philosophie,
And they are full with it: Heere Ile stay,
And tarry till my gallant youths come foorth.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: You mad-man, wild-oats, mad-cap, where art thou?

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: Heere afore.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Oh ware what loue is? Ned hath found the scent;
And if the Connie chaunce to misse her Burrough,
Shee's ouer-borne y faith, she cannot stand it.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: I know that voyce, or I am much deceiued.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Come, why loyter wee? this is the Dore:
But soft, heere's one asleepe.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Come, let mee feele:
Oh tis some Rogue or other; spurne him, spurne him.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.p: Be not so wilfull, prethee let him lie.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Come backe, come backe, for wee are past the house
Yonder's Matheas Chamber with the light.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Well fare a head, or I had been discride.
Gods mee, what make the Youngsters heere so late?
I am a Rouge, and spurne him: well Iacke sauce,
The Rogue is waking yet, to marre your sport.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: Matt, Mistris Mathea; where be these Girles?

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.p: Who's there below?

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: Thy Ned, kind Ned, thine honest trusty Ned.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: No, no, it is the Frenchman in his stead,
That Mounsieur motlicoate that can dissemble:
Heare you Frenchman, packe to your Whores in Fraunce;
Though I am Portingale by the Fathers side,
And therefore should be lustfull, wanton, light;
Yet goodman Goosecap, I will let you know,
That I haue so much English by the Mother,
That no bace slauering French shall make me stoope:
And so, sir Dan-delion fare you well.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: What speachlesse, not a word: why how now Ned?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: The Wench hath tane him downe,
He hanges his head.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: You Dan-de-lion, you that talke so well:
Harke you a word or two good Mistris Matt,
Did you appoynt your Friends to meete you heere,
And being come, tell vs of Whores in Fraunce,
A Spanish lennet, and an English Mare,
A Mongrill, halfe a Dogge and halfe a Bitch;
With Tran-dido, Dil-dido, and I know not what?
Heare you, if you'le run away with Ned,
And be content to take me as you find me,
Why so law, I am yours: if otherwise,
Youle change your Ned, to be a Frenchmans Trull?
Why then, Madame Delion, Ie vous lassera a Die, et la bon fortune.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: That voyce assures mee, that it is my Loue:
Say truly, Art thou my Ned? art thou my Loue?

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Swounds who should I be but Ned?
You make me sweare.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: Who speake you to? Mathea who's below?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.p: Marina.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: Young maister Haruy? for that voyce saith so.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Speake sister Matt, is not my true Loue there?

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.p: Ned is.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Not maister Heigham?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Laurentia, heere.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Yfayth thou'rt welcome.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Better cannot Fall.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.p: Sweete, so art thou.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: As much to mine.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Nay Gentles, welcome all.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Here's cunning harlotries, they feed these off
With welcome, and kind words, whilst other Lads.
Reuell in that delight they should possesse:
Good Girls, I promise you I like you well.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Say maister Haruy, saw you, as you came,
That Leacher, which my Sire appoynts my man;
I meane that wanton base Italian,
That Spannish-leather spruce companion:
That anticke Ape trickt vp in fashion?
Had the Asse come, I'de learne him, difference been
Betwixt an English Gentleman and him.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: How would you vse him. (sweete).
If he should come?

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Nay nothing (sweet) but only wash his crowne:
Why the Asse wooes in such an amorous key,
That he presumes no Wench should say him nay:
Hee slauers not his Fingers, wipes his Bill,
And sweares in fayth you shall, in fayth I will;
That I am almost madd to bide his wocing.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Looke what he said in word, Ile act in doing.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Leaue thought of him, for day steales on apace,
And to our Loues: Will you performe your words;
All things are ready, and the Parson stands,
'To ioyne as hearts in hearts, our hands in hands,
Night fauours vs, the thing is quickly done,
Then trusse vp bagg and Bagages, and be gone:
And ere the morninge, to augment your ioyes,
Weele make you mothers of sixe goodly Boyes.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Promise them three good Ned, and say no more.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: But Ile get three, and if I gette not foure.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Theres a sound Carde at Maw, a lustie lad,
Your father thought him well, when one he had,

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: What say you sweetes, will you performe your wordes?

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.l: Loue to true loue, no lesser meede affordes?
Wee say we loue you, and that loues fayre breath
Shall lead vs with you round about the Earth:
And that our loues, vowes, wordes, may all proue true,
Prepare your Armes, for thus we flie to you. they Embrace.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: This workes like waxe, now ere to morrow day,
If you two ply it but as well as I,
Weele worke our landes out of Pisaros Daughters:
And can sell all our bondes in their great Bellies,
When the slaue knowes it, how the Roge will curse.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: Sweete hart.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: Matt.

sp.speaker: Mathe.
sp.p: Where art thou.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Mathe.
sp.p: Oh Iesus heres our father.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: The Diuell he is.

sp.speaker: Haru
sp.p: Maister Pisaro, twenty times God morrow.

sp.speaker: Pisa,
sp.l: Good morrow? now I tell you Gentlemen,
You wrong and moue my patience ouermuch,
What will you Rob me, Kill me, Cutte my Throte:
And set mine owne bloud here against me too,
You huswifes? Baggages? or what is worse,
Wilfull, stoubborne, disobedient:
Vse it not Gentlemen, abuse me not,
Newgate hath rome, theres law enough in England,

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Be not so testie, heare what we can say.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Will you be wiu'de? first learne to keepe a wife,
Learne to be thriftie, learne to keepe your Lands,
And learne to pay your debts to, I aduise, else.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: What else, what Lands, what Debts, what will you doe?
Haue you not Land in Morgage for your mony,
Nay since tis so, we owe you not a Penny,
Frette not, Fume not, neuer bende the Browe:
You take Tenn in the hundred more then Law,
We can complayne, extortion, simony,
Newgate hath Rome, thers Law enough in England.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Prethe haue done.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Prethy me no Prethies.
Here is my wife, Sbloud touch her, if thou darst,
Hearst thou, Ile lie with her before thy face,
Against the Crosse in Cheape, here, any where.
What you old craftie Fox you.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Ned, stop there.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Nay, nay speake out, beare witnesse Gentlemen,
Whers Mowche, charge my Musket, bring me my Bill,
For here are some that meane to Rob thy maister.
I am a Fox with you, well Iack sawce,
Beware least for a Goose, I pray on you.
In baggages, Mowche make fast the doore.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: A vengeance on ill lucke,

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: What neuer storme,
But bridle anger with wise gouernment.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Whom? Anthony our friend, Ah now our hopes,
Are found too light to ballance our ill happes.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Tut nere say so, for Anthony
Is not deuoyde of meanes to helpe his Friends.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Swounds, what a diuell made he foorth so late
Ile lay my life twas hee that fainde to sleepe,
And we all vnsuspitious, tearmde a Roage:
Oh God, had I but knowne him; if I had,
I would haue writt such Letters with my Sword
Vpon the bald skin of his parching pate,
That he should nere haue liude to crosse vs more.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: These menaces are vaine, and helpeth naught:
But I haue in the deapth of my conceit
Found out a more materiall stratagem:
Harke Maister Walgraue, yours craues quicke dispatch,
About it straight, stay not to say farewell. Exit Walgraue.
You Maister Heigham, hie you to your Chamber,
And stirre not foorth, my shaddow, or my selfe,
Will in the morning earely visit you;
Build on my promise sir, and good night. Exit Heigham.
Last, yet as great in loue, as to the first:
Yf you remember, once I told a iest,
How feigning to be sicke, a Friend of mine
Possest the happy issue of his Loue:
That counterfeited humor must you play;
I need not to instruct, you can conceiue,
Vse maister Browne your Host, as chiefe in this:
But first, to make the matter seeme more true,
Sickly and sadly bid the churle good night;
I heare him at the Window, there he is.
Now for a tricke to ouerreach the Diuell.
I tell you sir, you wrong my maister much,
And then to make amends, you giue hard words:
H'ath been a friend to you; nay more, a Father:
I promise you, tis most vngently done.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: I, well said Mouche, now I see thy loue,
And thou shalt see mine, one day if I liue.
None but my Daughters sir, hanges for your tooth:
I'de rather see them hang'd first, ere you get them.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Maister Pisaro, heare a dead man speake,
Who singes the wofull accents of his end.
I doe confesse I loue; then let not loue
Proue the sad engine of my liues remooue:
Marinaes rich Possession was my blisse?
Then in her losse, all ioy eclipsed is:
As euery Plant takes vertue of the Sunne;
So from her Eyes, this life and beeing sprung:
But now debard of those cleare shyning Rayes,
Death for Earth gapes, and Earth to Death obeyes:
Each word thou spakst, (oh speake not so againe)
Bore Deaths true image on the Word ingrauen;
Which as it flue mixt with Heauens ayerie breath,
Summond the dreadfull Sessions of my death:
I leaue thee to thy wish, and may th'euent
Prooue equall to thy hope and hearts content.
Marina to that hap, that happiest is;
My Body to the Graue, my Soule to blisse.
Haue I done well?

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: Excellent well in troth.

sp.speaker: Pisar.
sp.l: I, goe; I, goe: your words moue me as much,
As doth a Stone being cast against the ayre.
sp.p: But soft, What Light is that? What Folkes be those? Oh tis Aluaro & his other Friends, Ile downe & let them in.

div.stage: Enter Belman, Frisco, Vandalle, Delion, & Aluaro.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Where are we now gaffer Buttericke?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why know you not Croched-friers, where be your wits?

sp.speaker: Aluar.
sp.p: Wat be tis Crosh-viers? vidite padre dare; tacke you dat, me fal troble you no farre.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I thanke you Gentlemen, good night:
Good night Frisco.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Farewell Buttericke, what a Clowne it is:
Come on my maisters merrily, Ile knocke at the dore.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Who's theere, our three wise Woers,
Blockhead our man? had he not been,
They might haue hanged them selues,
For any Wenches they had hit vpon:
Good morrow, or good den, I know not whether.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Monsieur de Mowche, wat macke you out de Houis so late?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: What, what, young men & sluggards fy for shame
You trifle time at home about vaine toyes,
Whilst others in the meane time, steale your Brides:
I tell you sir, the English Gentlemen
Had wel-ny mated you, and mee, and all;
The Dores were open, and the Girles abroad,
Their Sweet-hearts ready to receiue them to:
And gone forsooth they had been, had not I
(I thinke by reuelation) stopt their flight:
But I haue coopt them vp, and so will keepe them.
But sirra Frisco, where's the man I sent for?
Whose Cloake haue you got there?
How now, where's Vandalle?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: For-sooth he is not heere:
Maister Mendall you meane, doe you not?

sp.speaker: Pisar.
sp.l: Why logerhead, him I sent for, where is he?
Where hast thou been? How hast thou spent thy time?
Did I not send thee to my Sonne Vandalle?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: I M. Mendall; why forsooth I was at his Chamber, and wee were comming hitherward, and he was very hot, and bade me carry his Cloake; and I no sooner had it, but he (being very light) firkes me downe on the left hand, and I turnd downe on the left hand, and so lost him.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Why then you turnd togeather, Asse.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: No sir, we neuer saw one another since.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Why, turnd you not both on the left hand?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: No for-sooth we turnd both on the left hand.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Hoyda, why yet you went both togeather.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Ah no, we went cleane contrary one from another.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Why Dolt, why Patch, why Asse,
On which hand turnd yee?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Alas, alas, I cannot tell for-sooth, it was so darke I could not see, on which hand we turnd: But I am sure we turnd one way.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Was euer creature plagud with such a Dolt?
My Sonne Vandalle now hath lost himselfe,
And shall all night goe straying bout the Towne;
Or meete with some strange Watch that knowes him not;
And all by such an arrant Asse as this.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: No, no, you may soone smel the Dutchmans lodging: Now for a Figure: Out alas, what's yonder?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Hoyda, hoyda, a Basket: it turnes, hoe.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Peace ye Villaine, and let's see who's there? Goe looke about the House; where are our weapons? What might this meane?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Looke, looke, looke; there's one in it, he peeps out: Is there nere a Stone here to hurle at his Nose.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: What, wouldst thou breake my Windowes with a Stone? How now, who's there, who are you sir?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Looke, he peepes out againe: Oh it's M. Mendall, it's M. Mendall: how got he vp thither?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: What, my Sonne Vandalle, how comes this to passe?

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Signor Vandalle, wat do yo goe to de wenshe in de Basket?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Oh Vadere, Vadere, here be sush cruell Dochterkens, ick ben also wery, also wery, also cold; for be in dit little Basket: lo prey helpe dene.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p:
He lookes like the signe of the Mouth without Bishops gate, gaping, and a great Face, and a great Head,
and no Body.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Why how now Sonne, what haue your Adamants
Drawne you vp so farre, and there left you hanging
Twixt Heauen and Earth like Mahomets Sepulchre?

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: They did vnkindly, who so ere they were,
That plagu'd him here, like Tantalus in Hell,
To touch his Lippes like the desired Fruite,
And then to snatch it from his gaping Chappes.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: A little farder signor Vandalle, and dan you may put v hed into de windo and cash de Wensh.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Ick prey Vader dat you helpe de mee, Ick prey Goddie Vader.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Helpe you, but how?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Cut the Rope.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Sir, Ile goe in and see,
And if I can, Ile let him downe to you.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Doe gentle Mouche: Why but here's a iest;
They say, high climers haue the greatest falles:
If you should fall; as how youle doe I know not,
Birlady I should doubt me of my Sonne:
Pray to the Rope to hold: Art thou there Mouche?

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: Yes sir, now you may chuse, whether youle stay till I let him downe, or whether I shall cut him downe?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Cut him downe maister Mowse, cut him downe And let's see, how hele tumble.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Why sauce, who ask'd your counsaile?
Let him downe.
What, with a Cusshion too? why you prouided
To lead your life as did Diogines;
And for a Tubb, to creepe into a Basket.

sp.speaker: Vanda.
sp.p: Ick sall seg v Vader, Ick quame here to your Huise and spreake tol de Dochterken.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: M. Mendall, you are welcome out of the Basket: I smell a Ratt it was not for nothing, that you lost me.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Oh skellum, you run away from me.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: I thought so sirra, you gaue him the flip.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Faw, no for-sooth; Ile tell you how it was: when we come from Bucklers-Burie into Corn-Wale, and I had taken the Cloake, then you should haue turnd downe on your left hand and so haue gone right forward, and so turnd vp againe, and so haue crost the streate; and you like an Asse.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Why how now Rascall; is your manners such?
You asse, you Dolt, why led you him through Corn-hill,
Your way had been to come through Canning streete.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Why so I did sir.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Why thou seest yee were in Corn-Hill.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Indeed sir there was three faults, the Night was darke, Maister Mendall drunke, and I sleepy, that we could not tell very well, which way we went.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Sirra I owe for this a Cudgelling:
But Gentlemen, sith things haue faulne out so,
And for I see Vandalle quakes for cold,
This night accept your Lodginges in my house,
And in the morning forward with your marriage,
Come on my sonnes, sirra fetch vp more wood.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Nay neuer weepe Marina for the matter,
Teares are but signes of sorrow, helping not.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Would it not madde one to be crost as I,
Being in the very hight of my desire?
The strangers frustrate all: our true loue's come,
Nay more, euen at the doore, and Haruies armes
Spred as a Rayne-bow ready to receiue me,
And then my Father meete vs: Oh God, oh God.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Weepe who that list for me, y faith not I,
Though I am youngest yet my stomack's great:
Nor tis not father, friends, nor any one,
Shall make me wed the man I cannot loue:
Ile haue my will ynfayth, y'fayth I will.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Let vs determine Sisters what to doe,
My father meanes to wed vs in the morning,
And therefore something must be thought vpon.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Weele to our father and so know his minde,
I and his reason too, we are no fooles,
Or Babes neither, to be fedde with words.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Agreede, agreede: but who shall speake for all?

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: No I.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Thou wilt not speake for crying.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Yes, yes I warrant you, that humors left,
Bee I but mou'de a little, I shall speake,
And anger him I feare, ere I haue done.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Whom Anthony our friend, our Schoole-maister?
Now helpe vs Gentle Anthony, or neuer.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: What is your hastie running chang'd to prayer,
Say, where were you going?

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Euen to our father,
To know what he intendes to doe with vs.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Tis bootlesse trust mee, for he is resolu'd
To marry you to.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: The Strangers.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: Y fayth he is.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Y fayth he shall not.
Frenchman, be sure weele plucke a Crow together,
Before you force mee giue my hand at Church.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Come to our Father speach this comfort finds,
That we may scould out griefe, and ease our mindes.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Stay, Stay Marina, and aduise you better,
It is not Force, but Pollicie must serue:
The Dores are lockt, your Father keepes the Keye,
Wherefore vnpossible to scape away:
Yet haue I plotted, and deuis'd a drift,
To frustrate your intended mariages,
And giue you full possession of your ioyes:
Laurentia, ere the mornings light appeare,
You must play Anthony in my disguise.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.p: Anthony, what of vs? What shall we weare?

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: Anthony, what of vs? What shall we weare?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Soft, soft, you are too forward Girles, I sweare,
For you some other drift deuisd must bee?
One shaddow for a substance: this is shee.
Nay weepe not sweetes, repose vpon my care,
For all alike, or good or bad shall share:
You will haue Haruie, you Heigham, and you Ned;
You shall haue all your wish, or be I dead:
For sooner may one day the Sea lie still,
Then once restraine a Woman of her will.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Sweete Anthony, how shall we quit thy hire?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Not gifts, but your contentments I desire:
To helpe my Countrimen I cast about,
For Strangers loues blase fresh, but soone burne out:
Sweete rest dwell heere, and frightfull feare obiure,
These eyes shall wake to make your rest secure:
For ere againe dull night the dull eyes charmes,
Each one shall fould her Husband in her armes:
Which if it chaunce, we may auouch it still,
Women & Maydes will alwayes haue their will.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Are Wood & Coales brought vp to make a fire?
Is the Meate spitted ready to lie downe:
For Bakemeates Ile haue none, the world's too hard:
There's Geese too, now I remember mee;
Bid Mawdlin lay the Giblets in Past,
Here's nothing thought vpon, but what I doe.
Stay Frisco, see who ringes: looke to the Dore,
Let none come in I charge, were he my Father,
Ile keepe them whilst I haue them: Frisco, who is it?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: She is come ynfayth.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Who is come?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Mistris Sushaunce, Mistris Moores daughter.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Mistris Susan, Asse? Oh she must come in.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Hang him, if he keepe out a Wench:
Yf the Wench keepe not out him, so it is.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Welcome Mistris Susan, welcome;
I little thought you would haue come to night;
But welcome (trust me) are you to my house:
What, doth your Mother mende? doth she recouer?
I promise you I am sorry for her sicknesse.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: She's better then she was, I thanke God for it,

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Now afore God she is a sweete smugge Girle,
One might doe good on her; the flesh is frayle,
Man hath infirmitie, and such a Bride,
Were able to change Age to hot desire:
Harke you Sweet-heart,
To morrow are my Daughters to be wedde,
I pray you take the paines to goe with them.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: If sir youle giue me leaue, Ile waight on them.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Yes marry shall you, and a thousand thankes,
Such company as you my Daughters want,
Maydes must grace Maydes, when they are married:
Ist not a merry life (thinkes thou) to wed,
For to imbrace, and be imbrac'd abed.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: I know not what you meane sir.
Heere's an old Ferret Pol-cat.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: You may doe, if youle follow mine aduice;
I tell thee Mouse, I knew a Wench as nice:
Well, shee's at rest poore soule, I meane my Wife,
That thought (alas good heart) Loue was a toy,
Vntill (well, that time is gon and past away)
But why speake I of this: Harke yee Sweeting,
There's more in Wedlocke, then the name can shew;
And now (birlady) you are ripe in yeares:
And yet take heed Wench, there lyes a Pad in Straw;

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Old Fornicator, had I my Dagger,
Ide breake his Costard.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Young men are slippery, fickle, wauering;
Constant abiding graceth none but Age:
Then Maydes should now waxe wise, and doe so,
As to chuse constant men, let fickle goe,
Youth's vnregarded, and vnhonoured:
An auncient Man doth make a Mayde a Matron:
And is not that an Honour, how say you? how say you?

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Yes forsooth.
(Oh old lust will you neuer let me goe.)

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: You say right well, and doe but thinke thereon,
How Husbands, honored yeares, long car'd-for wealth,
Wise stayednesse, Experient gouernment,
Doth grace the Mayde, that thus is made a Wise,
And you will wish your selfe such, on my life.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: I thinke I must turne womankind altogeather,
And scratch out his eyes:
For as long as he can see me, hele nere let me goe.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: But goe (sweet-heart) to bed, I doe thee wrong,
The latenesse now, makes all our talke seeme long.
How now Mowche, be the Girles abed?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: Mathea (and it like you) faine would sleepe, but onely tarrieth for her bed-fellow.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Ha, you say well: come, light her to her Chamber,
Good rest wish I to thee; wish so to mee,
Then Susan and Pisaro shall agree:
Thinke but what ioy is neere your bed-fellow,
Such may be yours; take counsaile of your Pillow:
To morrow weele talke more; and so good night,
Thinke what is sayd, may bee, if all hit right.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: What, haue I past the Pikes: knowes he not Ned?
I thinke I haue deseru'd his Daughters bed.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Tis well, tis well: but this let me request,
You keepe vnknowne, till you be laide to rest:
And then a good hand speed you.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Tut, nere feare mee,
We two abed shall neuer disagree.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: I haue stood still all this while, and could not speake for laughing: Lord what a Dialogue hath there bin betweene Age and Youth. You do good on her? euen as much as my Dutchman will doe on my young Mistris: Maister, follow my counsaile; then send for M. Heigham to helpe him, for Ile lay my Cappe to two Pence, that hee will be asleepe to morrow at night, when he should goe to bed to her: Marry for the Italian, he is of an other humor, for therele be no dealings with him, till midnight; for hee must slauer all the Wenches in the house at parting, or he is no body: hee hath been but a litle while at our House, yet in that small time, hee hath lickt more Grease from our Mawdlins lippes, then would haue seru'd London Kitchin-stuffe this tweluemonth. Yet for my money, well fare the Frenchman, Oh hee is a forward Lad, for heele no sooner come from the Church, but heele fly to the Chamber; why heele read his Lesson so often in the day time, that at night like an apt Scholler, heele be ready to sell his old Booke to buye him a new. Oh the generation of Languages that our House will bring foorth: why euery Bedd will haue a propper speach to himselfe, and haue the Founders name written vpon it in faire Cappitall letters, Heere lay, and so foorth.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Youle be a villaine still: Looke who's at dore?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p:
Nay by the Masse, you are M. Porter, for Ile be hang'd if you loose that office, hauing so pretty a morsell vnder your keeping: I goe (old huddle) for the best Nose at smelling out a Pin-fold, that I know: well, take heede, you may happes picke vp Wormes so long, that at length
some of them get into your Nose, and neuer out after: But what an Asse am I to thinke so, considering all the Lodginges are taken vp already, and there's not a Dog-kennell empty for a strange Worme to breed in.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: The day is broke; Mathea and young Ned,
By this time, are so surely linckt togeather,
That none in London can forbid the Banes.
Laurentia she is neere prouided for:
So that if Haruies pollicie but hold,
Elsewheare the Strangers may goe seeke them Wiues:
But heere they come.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Six a clocke say you; trust mee, forward dayes:
Harke you Mowche, hic you to Church,
Bid M Bewford be in readinesse:
Where goe you, that way?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: For my Cloake, sir.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Oh tis well: and M. Browne,
Trust mee, your earely stirring makes me muse,
Is it to mee your businesse?

sp.speaker: Brown.
sp.l: Euen to your selfe:
I come (I thinke) to bring you welcome newes,

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: And welcome newes,
More welcome makes the bringer:
Speake, speake, good M. Browne, I long to heare them.

sp.speaker: Brow.
sp.l: Then this it is. Young Haruie late last night,
Full weake and sickly came vnto his lodging,
From whence this suddaine mallady proceedes:
Tis all vncertaine, the Doctors and his Friends
Affirme his health is vnrecouerable:
Young Heigham and Ned Walgraue lately left him,
And I came hither to informe you of it.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Young M. Haruie sicke; now afore God
The newes bites neere the Bone: for should he die,
His Liuing morgaged would be redeemed,
For not these three months doth the Bond beare date:
Die now, marry God in heauen defend it;
Oh my sweete Lands, loose thee, nay loose my life:
And which is worst, I dare not aske mine owne,
For I take two and twenty in the hundred,
When the Law giues but ten: But should he liue,
Hee carelesse would haue left the debt vnpaide,
Then had the Lands been mine Pisaros owne,
Mine, mine owne Land, mine owne Possession.

sp.speaker: Brow.
sp.p: Nay heare mee out.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: You'r out too much already,
Vnlesse you giue him life, and mee his Land.

sp.speaker: Brow.
sp.l: Whether tis loue to you, or to your Daughter,
I know not certaine; but the Gentleman
Hath made a deed of gift of all his Lands,
Vnto your beautious Daughter faire Marina.

sp.speaker: Pesa.
sp.l: Ha, say that word againe, say it againe,
A good thing cannot be too often spoken:
Marina say you, are you sure twas shee,
Or Mary, Margery; or some other Mayde?

sp.speaker: Brow.
sp.l: To none but your Daughter faire Marina;
And for the gift might be more forcible,
Your neighbour maister Moore aduised vs,
(Who is a witnesse of young Haruies Will)
Sicke as hee is, to bring him to your house:
I know they are not farre, but doe attende,
That they may know, what welcome they shall haue.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: What welcome sir; as welcome as new life
Giuen to the poore condemned Prisoner:
Returne (good maister Browne) assure their welcome,
Say it, nay sweare it; for they'r welcome truly:
For welcome are they to mee which bring Gold.
See downe who knockes; it may be there they are:
Frisco, call downe my Sonnes, bid the Girles rise:
Where's Mowche; what, is he gon or no?
Oh heare you siera, bring along with you
Maister Balsaro the Spanish Marchant.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Many Balsaros I; Ile to my Loue:
And thankes to Anthony for this escape.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Stay, take vs with you. Harke, they knocke againe,
Come my soules comfort, thou good newes bringer,
I must needes hugge thee euen for pure affection.

div.stage: Enter Haruie brought in a Chaire, Moore, Browne, Aluaro, Vandalle, Delion, and Frisco.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Lift softly (good my friends) for hurting him.
Looke chearely sir, you'r welcome to my house.
Harke M. Vandalle, and my other Sonnes,
Seeme to be sad as grieuing for his sicknesse,
But inwardly reioyce. Maister Vandalle,
Signor Aluaro, Monsieur Delion,
Bid my Friend welcome, pray bid him welcome:
Take a good heart; I doubt not (by Gods leaue)
You shall recouer and doe well enough:
(Yf I should thinke so, I should hange my selfe.)
Frisco, goe bid Marina come to mee. Exit Frisco.
You are a Witnesse sir, of this mans Will:
What thinke you M. Moore, what say you to't?

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: Maister Pisaro, follow mine aduice:
You see the Gentleman cannot escape,
Then let him straight be wedded to your Daughter;
So during life time, she shall hold his Land,
When now (beeing nor kith nor kin to him)
For all the deed of Gift, that he hath seald,
His younger Brother will inioy the Land.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Marry my Daughter: no birlady.
Heare you Aluaro, my Friend counsaile mee,
Seeing young M. Haruie is so sicke,
To marry him incontinent to my Daughter.
Or else the gift he hath bestowde, is vaine:
Marry and hee recouer; no my Sonne,
I will not loose thy loue, for all his Land.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Here you padre, do no lose his Lands, his hundred pont per anno tis wort to hauar; let him haue de matresse Marina in de mariage, tis but vor me to attendre vne day more: if he will no die, I sal giue him sush a Drincke, sush a Potion sal mak him giue de Bonos noches to all de world.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Aluaro, here's my Keyes, take all I haue,
My Money, Plate, Wealth, Iewels, Daughter too:
Now God be thanked, that I haue a Daughter, worthy to be Aluaro bed fellow:
Oh how I doe admire and prayse thy wit,
Ile straight about it: Heare you Maister Moore.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Nay sayth hee's sicke, therefore though hee be come, yet he can doe you no good; there's no remedy but euen to put your selfe into the hands of the Italian, that by that time that he hath past his grouth, young Haruie will be in case to come vpon it with a sise of fresh force.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Is my Loue come, & sicke? I, now thou louest me,
How my heart ioyes: Oh God, get I my will,
Ile driue away that Sicknesse with a kisse:
I need not faine, for I could weepe for ioy.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: It shall be so; come hither Daughter.
Maister Haruie, that you may see my loue
Comes from a single heart vnfaynedly,
See heere my Daughter, her I make thine owne:
Nay looke not strange, before these Gentlemen,
I freely yeeld Marina for thy Wife.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Stay, stay good sir, forbeare this idle worke,
My soule, is labouring for a higher place,
Then this vaine transitorie world can yeeld:
What, would you wed your Daughter to a Graue?
For this is but Deaths modell in mans shape:
You and Aluaro happie liue togeather:
Happy were I, to see you liue togeather.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Come sir, I trust you shall doe well againe:
Heere, heere, it must be so; God giue you ioy,
And blesse you (not a day to liue togeather.)

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Hort ye broder, will ye let den ander heb your Wiue? nempt haer, nempt haer your selue?

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: No, no; tush you be de foole, here be dat sal spoyle de mariage of hem: you haue deceue me of de fine Wensh signor Haruey, but I sal deceue you of de mush Land.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.p: Are all things sure Father, is all dispatch'd?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: What intrest we haue, we yeeld it you:
Are you now satisfied, or restes there ought?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Nay Father, nothing doth remaine, but thankes:
Thankes to your selfe first, that disdayning mee,
Yet loude my Lands, and for them gaue a Wife.
But next, vnto Aluaro let me turne,
To courtious gentle louing kind Aluaro,
That rather then to see me die for loue,
For very loue, would loose his beawtious Loue.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Signor Aluaro, giue him de ting quickly sal make hem dy, autremant you sal lose de fine Wensh.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Oyime che hauesse allhora appressata la mano al mio core, ô suen curato ate, I che longo sei tu arriuato, ô cieli, ô terra.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Am I awake? or doe deluding Dreames
Make that seeme true, which most my soule did feare?

sp.speaker: Haru
sp.l: Nay fayth Father, it's very certaine true,
I am as well as any man on earth:
Am I sicke sirres? Looke here, is Haruie sicke?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: What shall I doe? What shall I say?
Did not you counsaile mee to wed my Childe?
What Potion? Where's your helpe, your remedy.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: I hope more happy Starres will reigne to day,
And don Aluaro haue more company.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Now Anthony, this cottens as it should,
And euery thing sorts to his wish'd effect:
Haruie ioyes Moll: my Dutchman and the French,
Thinking all sure, laughs at Aluaros hap;
But quickly I shall marre that merrie vaine,
And make your Fortunes equall with your Friends.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Sirra Mowche, what answere brought you backe?
Will maister Balsaro come, as I requested?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: Maister Balsaro; I know not who you meane.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Know you not Asse, did I not send thee for him?
Did not I bid thee bring him, with the Parson?
What answere made hee, will hee come or no?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Sent me for him: why sir, you sent not mee,
I neither went for him, nor for the Parson:
I am glad to see your Worship is so merrie. Knocke.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Hence you forgetfull dolt:
Looke downe who knockes?

sp.speaker: Frisco.
sp.p: Oh Maister, hange your selfe: nay neuer stay for a Sessions: Maister Vandalle confesse your selfe, desire the people to pray for you; for your Bride shee is gone: Laurentia is run away.

sp.speaker: Vanda.
sp.p: Oh de Diabolo, de mal-fortune: is matresse Laurentia gaen awech?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: First tell mee that I am a liuelesse coarse;
Tell mee of Doomes-day, tell mee what you will,
Before you say Laurentia is gone.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Maister Vandalle, how doe you feele your selfe?
What, hang the head? fie man for shame I say,
Looke not so heauie on your marriage day.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Oh blame him not, his griefe is quickly spide,
That is a Bridegroome, and yet wants his Bride.

sp.speaker: Bals.
sp.l: Maister Pisaro, and Gentlemen, good day to all:
According sir, as you requested mee,
This morne I made repaire vnto the Tower,
Where as Laurentia now was married:
And sir, I did expect your comming thither;
Yet in your absence, wee perform'd the rites:
Therefore I pray sir, bid God giue them ioy.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: He tels you true, Laurentia is my Wife;
Who knowing that her Sisters must be wed;
Presuming also, that you'le bid her welcome,
Are come to beare them company to Church.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: You come too late, the Mariage rites are done:
Yet welcome twenty-fold vnto the Feast.
How say you sirs, did not I tell you true,
These Wenches would haue vs, and none of you.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: I cannot say for these; but on my life,
This loues a Cusshion better then a Wife.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: And reason too, that Cusshion fell out right,
Else hard had been his lodging all last night.

sp.speaker: Bals.
sp.p: Maister Pisaro, why stand you speachlesse thus?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Anger, and extreame griefe enforceth mee.
Pray sir, who bade you meete mee at the Tower?

sp.speaker: Bals.
sp.p: Who sir; your man sir, Mowche; here he is.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: Who I sir, meane you mee? you are a iesting man.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Thou art a Villaine, a dissembling Wretch,
Worser then Anthony whom I kept last:
Fetch me an Officer, Ile hamper you,
And make you sing at Bride-well for this tricke:
For well he hath deserude it, that would sweare
He went not foorth a dores at my appoyntment.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: So sweare I still, I went not foorth to day.

sp.speaker: Bals.
sp.p: Why arrant lyer, wert thou not with mee?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: How say you maister Browne, went he not foorth?

sp.speaker: Brow.
sp.p: Hee, or his likenesse did, I know not whether.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: What likenesse can there be besides himselfe?

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: My selfe (forsooth) that tooke his shape vpon me,
I was that Mowche that you sent from home:
And that same Mowche that deceiued you,
Effected to possesse this Gentleman:
Which to attaine, I thus be guil'd you all.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: This is excellent, this is as fine as a Fiddle: you M. Heigham got the Wench in Mowches apparell; now let Mowche put on her apparell, and be married to the Dutchman: How thinke you, is it not a good vize?

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: Maister Pisaro, shake off melancholy,
When thinges are helpelesse, patience must be vs'd.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Talke of Patience? Ile not beare these wronges:
Goe call downe Matt, and mistris Susan Moore,
Tis well that of all three, wee haue one sure.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: Mistris Susan Moore, who doe you meane sir?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Whom should I meane sir, but your Daughter?

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: You'r very pleasant sir: but tell me this,
When did you see her, that you speake of her?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: I, late yester-night, when she came heere to bed.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: You are deceiu'd, my Daughter lay not heere,
But watch'd with her sicke mother all last night.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: I am glad you are so pleasant M Moore,
You'r loth that Susan should be held a sluggard:
What man, t'was late before she went to bed,
And therefore time enough to rise againe.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: Maister Pisaro, doe you floute your friends;
I well perceiue if I had troubled you,
I should haue had it in my dish ere now:
Susan lie heere? 'am sure when I came foorth,
I left her fast asleepe in bed at home;
Tis more then neighbour-hood to vse me thus.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: A bed at your house? tell me I am madd,
Did not I let her in adores my selfe,
Spoke to her, talk'd with her, and canuast with her;
And yet she lay not heere? What say you sirra?

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: She did, she did; I brought her to her Chamber.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: I say he lyes (that sayth so) in his throat.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: Masse now I remember me, I lye indeed.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Oh how this frets mee: Frisco, what say you?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: What say I? Marry I say, if shee lay not heere, there was a familiar in her likenesse; for I am sure my Maister and she were so familiar togeather, that he had almost shot the Gout out of his Toes endes, to make the Wench beleeue he had one tricke of youth in him. Yet now I remember mee shee did not lye heere; and the reason is, because shee doth lye heere, and is now abed with mistris Mathea; witnesse whereof, I haue set to my Hand & Seale, and meane presently to fetch her.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Doe so Frisco. Gentlemen and Friends,
Now shall you see how I am wrong'd by him.
Lay shee not heere? I thinke the world's growne wise,
Plaine folkes (as I) shall not know how to liue.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Shee comes, shee comes: a Hall, a Hall.

div.stage: Enter Mathea and Walgraue in Womans attire.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Nay blush not wench, feare not, looke chearfully.
Good morrow Father; Good morrow Gentlemen:
Nay stare not, looke you heere, no monster I,
But euen plaine Ned: and heere stands Matt my Wife.
Know you her Frenchman? But she knowes me better.
Father, pray Father, let mee haue your blessing,
For I haue blest you with a goodly Sonne;
Tis breeding heere yfayth, a iolly Boy.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: I am vndone, a reprobate, a slaue;
A scorne, a laughter, and a iesting stocke:
Giue mee my Child, giue mee my Daughter from you.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: Maister Pisaro, tis in vaine to fret,
And fume, and storme, it little now auayles:
These Gentlemen haue with your Daughters helpe,
Outstript you in your subtile enterprises:
And therefore, seeing they are well descended,
Turne hate to loue, and let them haue their Loues,

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Is it euen so; why then I see that still,
Doe what we can, Women will haue their Will.
Gentlemen, you haue outreacht mee now,
Which nere before you, any yet could doe:
You, that I thought should be my Sonnes indeed,
Must be content, since there's no hope to speed:
Others haue got, what you did thinke to gaine;
And yet beleeue mee, they haue tooke some paine.
Well, take them, there; and with them, God giue ioy.
And Gentlemen, I doe intreat to morrow,
That you will Feaste with mee, for all this sorrow:
Though you are wedded, yet the Feast's not made:
Come let vs in, for all the stormes are past,
And heapes of ioy will follow on as fast.
